name: Left 4 Dead 2
description: Set in the zombie apocalypse, Left 4 Dead 2 (L4D2) is the highly anticipated sequel to the award-winning Left 4 Dead, the #1 co-op game of 2008. This co-operative action horror FPS takes you and your friends through the cities, swamps and cemeteries of the Deep South, from Savannah to New Orleans across five expansive campaigns.

reviews.review_text: Even though this game is over 9 years old it still holds up as being one of, if not THE best zombie game on the market. It's not only fun playing single player but it's hilarious when you can get three more friends to join in the zombie killing.  There's of course the standard Easy - Hard difficulities (Here being Easy, Medium, Advanced and Expert). So if you're looking for some mindless slaughtering to do you can put it on easy or if you and your friends is a tatical squad preparing for the zombie apacolypse this is a great way to start!  Also you don't have to play the first game to get into this one, all the maps and more from the first game is in this one. Even if you want to play oldschool there is a mode for that. Speaking of modes, there's Versus mode which is exactly what it sounds like, you control both the infected and the survivors in rounds. The one who ends the final map with the most points win. There is also a realism version of this mode which means the survivers can't see the green/orange/red glow around them as they used to.  There's also Survival which is aslo what it sounds like. Survive for X amount of time and you get bronze, silver or a gold medal depending on the requirments for the map you're playing.  Scavanger is the last major gamemode, here you play as survivor and infected and the objective is to fill a generator with gas. Who wins depends on which team's the fastest.  Then, finally, there's something called mutation. These are pretty much fun little mini modes. For example you have to try and survive an entire campaign on your own, you and all your teamates have katanas and can't get other weapons, you need to carry around a lawngnome to win etc.
Left 4 Dead was fun but with Left 4 Dead 2 it gets exciting new content across the board and plenty of it, Left 4 Dead 2 outdoes its predecessor and makes the zombie apocalypse an absolute blast.

The successor to Left 4 Dead, this second game adds new maps, new weapons, new special infected with new attacks and even new characters. But in many ways the most important different between the two games is the scoring system.  Without mods, the first games scoring system really did tend to induce rage. A single mistake on a map and you could lose so many points that teams would be totally demoralized and either fall apart (making the game effectively over) or just quit (making it absolutely over). For hardcore players this was half the fun, but for the average casual player it could make Left 4 Dead a little too frustrating.  Left 4 Dead 2 on the other hand had a far more forgiving score system allowing teams who fail badly on map 1 to still feel they have a good chance of clawing the in back in the next 3 or 4 maps. With party wipes being a little less likely due to the removal of the quad cap, Left 4 Dead 2 is still a game people can play causally and still enjoy. With the extra variety of a lot more special infected meaning a lot more variety in possible tactics, Left 4 Dead 2 is still one of the best team focused games that I have ever played.  If you have a small group of close friends who love winning through superior team work rather than superior twitch skills, Left 4 Dead 2 is one of the best PvP games you could try. But be warned, playing with random people you have never met can be rewarding, but more often than not it can be bloody annoying.  HOURS ON RECORD : I don't play this game on my public account. I have over 1500 my private account.

Left 4 Dead 2 is a hard game to review. The left 4 dead games 'both of them' are games that are unlike anything else I have ever played, they are games that quite literally changed my entire life. These games are the types of games that you can meet people on that will be friends for years to come and these games also have an unreal amount of replay value. you have campaign for the casual players with addon support so you have an almost endless amount of maps to play if you dont mind downloading more, you have versus which can be really fun, but sadly in both games unless you play with friends the community is either tryhards that care too much about winning or people that are so terrible that you wonder how they even got their computer running in the first place. Lastly there is survival, my personal favorite game mode. People in the survival community 'once you actually find the real survival players' are useually a nice bunch of people and its a game mode unlike the other two in a good way once you give it a chance. Honestly both of these games although they both are titled 'Left 4 Dead' are very different and many people i have run into tend to think of one game as simply better than the other, but objectively speaking this is simply not the case. Both games are too different to really make that kind of judgement. Both of these games are games that if you enjoy this type of gameplay, then you could waste thousands of hours on them.  But this brings up the biggest problem with these games, the people in them. Do enough searching and you will find people you can mingle with but the majority of public players in either game regardless of game mode are unbelieveably dumb. In vs also not just the really dumb people but you have the typical ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s found in any game based around pvp that seem to think that winning makes them more important somehow as a person and don't seem to realize that there is no reward for winning in a l4d games like there is in a competitive game like counter strike or dota with their tournaments.   Campaign is a really casual game mode compared to the other two but still there tends to be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in this game mode too sometimes, people that find joy in joining pub games just to grief their teammates for some reason and then leave without a word. Thankfully this is rare and most people in campaign are either mute or friendly.  Then there is survival, a game mode that brings me more enjoyment but also more frustration than any other mode. In L4D2 it seems to be a collection of people that for some stupid reason refuse to play anything except for the mall map, people that are actually really terrible at it too and can run laps for 100+ min on mall sure but could not get a gold on any other map to save their life. There is l4d1 survival as well which is a dif style of play but the community is dying off because all of the players who have been around a long time have gotten tired of the game and pubs are beyond stupid. Always either people trying to glitch a time or people so bad/dumb you wonder if they were dropped on their head as a baby 5 times.  All in all, You will enjoy the l4d games, both of them if you enjoy co-op based shooters, but you will have to endure a very mixed crowd of people regardless of game, with the first game haveing a somewhat more friendly crowd cause of the smaller community. I would recommend both games if you have the patience to search for people worth talking to or have someone to go into the game with.

In this game you will be introduced with a high-school football “Coach” but with a bad knee, a cold and sarcastic gambler and con artist Nick, Rochelle who is a low level production assistant and reporting on the evacuation for local TV station and a friendly mechanic Ellis.  As a start, the four survivors found themselves at an abandoned hotel roof by the rescue chopper. This is the start of Dead Center. So, they decided to reach the local mall where a second CEDA evacuation point is located. By their way after finishing correspondence with gun shop owner Whitaker, they discovered that the mall is overrun by infected. At such a situation Ellis helped the group to use a stock car and to travel towards New Orleans, probably the last standing city of America.  The Passing stands in between Dead Center and Dark Carnival just after The Sacrifice. The four of the L4D2 survivors when arrive at the bridge of Rayford they meet Francis, Louis and Zoey. Since they need to cross the bridge so they four found the other way. After fighting their way through a wedding reception of witch bride, the streets and under the river tour they meet up again with the original survivors who provided covering fire while filling up the generator or lowering the bridge.  Dark Carnival starts in a highway completely blocked by ditched vehicles. Starting from there survivors reached at an abandoned amusement park. At the park stadium Coach found a plan to use a large scale light show used by The Midnight Riders to signal the rescue chopper.  Yet bad luck… they found the chopper pilot is infected! Naturally, Nick killed him and it crashed so also Swamp Fever starts. So, crossing the swamps the group finally arrives at plantation mansion and makes radio contact with Virgil, a boat captain. But his boat starts to run low on diesel on the way to New Orleans. Hard rain starts, the survivors go to shore at Ducatel. Crossing a witch infested sugarcane mill finally they get gas from gas station and return back with fuels to signal Virgil.  Virgil drops the group at New Orleans where military is evacuating civilians across a bridge. But the four discovered that the city is completely overrun by infected and so the military is actually leaving the city before it is destroyed by air strike. However, survivors managed to reach the bridge and made contact with the military. Then crossing the bridge they were evacuated by chopper and the bridge was destroyed with the end of The Parish. More than 4 years after its release, this is still one of the very best (if not the best) co-operative FPS shooter, where teamwork is highly emphasized but you are also given complete freedom at doing whatever you want, although if you want to succeed easily in the missions, you will learn to enjoy and appreciate constant communication with your teammates.   The concept of the game has been clearly very well thought-out and over 400 hours later, i am still drawn to play this game and it never gets old. The campaign missions are great to familiarize yourself with the maps, the settings, the gameplay, the different infected and their distinctive attacks. Everything balances itself out at every turn. But the real strength of this game is its multiplayer. You simply cannot experience the full force of Left 4 Dead, without having played its many multiplayer modes. There are so many different game possibilities and different objectives. It is one of the very few games that can keep me going for several hours, irrespective if i'm tired or sleepy - the adrenaline rush just keeps me awake and the feeling of satisfaction if you work well as a team is simply tremendous.  There are also private game servers which offer even more customizable game modes. The standard versus mode for the official game is 4 vs 4. But on third-party servers, you will encounter 10 vs 10, which changes the game by enabling more chaos and way more fun. I highly recommend that you try it if you ever get tired of the official game modes and want to try something new and even more exciting.

Amazing game. A true example of innovation done right in gaming.  -Graphics: crisp, clean textues and environments. 720p and up.  -Frame Rate: 60fps and up.  -Sound: Audio is breathtaking, clear, and optimized.  -Gameplay: Incredible. A simple system that's easy for first time players to learn, yet complex to offer late game masters something to calculate with. Balanced enemies, spawn rates, weapons, movements, HP system, and ammo capacity. Can be as challenging, easy, or unforgiving as you want. Well tailored to any and all players.  -Level design: Environments are diverse and uniquely pathed to offer a different feel and strategy per level. Spawns and item placements are mostly randomized, yet still manages to make use of every corner of the maps. Direction and pace of play is linear, but never gets old or burdensome.  -Multiplayer: Fast connections, great server support, one button in game press to check your signal strength. Local, dedicated, and undedicated server support.  -Customization: Near everything can be modded to suit anything you can think up. Textures, sounds, maps, Ai, objectives, text.

If you don't have this game already, and like First Person Shooters... get it. It's sometimes on sale for only a few dollars, and on occasion has even been free for a weekend or Christmas.  The best co-op game I've ever played, hands down. I spent nearly a thousand hours playing campaign mode before even dipping a toe into Versus or Scavenge game modes. These (competitive) multiplayer modes are very fun also, but be aware that you will be expected to have mastered the learning curve BEFORE jumping into these - your teammates will expect you to know the game already, and there's virtually no on-the-job training, so to speak. ;)  L4D2 includes pretty much all the content of L4D1, and a bunch more besides - 4 new survivors, 3 new Special Infected, 5 new campaigns, new 'uncommon infected' specific to these new campaigns, and new player-usable items in every category. Plus an add-on workshop to customize your game when it finally starts feeling stale. In terms of play hours per dollar spent, no other game I have EVER played comes close.  So if you're wondering whether to get this game? Get it, especially if you can get it on sale. Even if you only play it a bit and put it aside for other things, you'll probably be glad you have it in your library to play with friends occasionally.

Left 4 Dead 2 is a game where four survivors attempt to survive and escape the zombie horde. If they survive or not, is up to you, and how you play.  Left 4 Dead 2 manages to be fast-paced in a genre of slow zombie survivals, but it also still manages to retain the tense and stressful nature of the rest of the zombie games. There is no aim down sights in the game, unless you are using a sniper rifle, similar to the rest of Valve's games. Another thing in line with the rest of Valve's work is the lack of regenerating health. In Left 4 Dead 2, players must use first aid kits in order to heal themselves, with adrenaline shots and painkillers acting as 'temporary' health. Much of your survival depends on how well you utilize your first-aid...  Do you save it in case something goes wrong, do you use it on someone else, or do you use it like it's the last chance you'll ever get...? Will you ever find more down the road?   These are the questions you'll quickly ask yourself and the rest of your party as you try to make it through.  Other than the healing items, there are various other items to keep an eye out for as well. Pipe bombs, molotovs, and even a jar of bile. Pipe bombs draw standard zombies to them with a loud beeping sound and a bright red light. In Left 4 Dead, loud sounds will attract zombies, and the pipe bomb in particular will keep them away from you, and will eventually kill them when it explodes. The molotov is a simple but effective weapon in keeping the horde away, it puts down a field of fire and it burns enemies. The last item is the bile jar. It attracts the horde to anything you throw it at, and they'll stay on it for a while, killing whatever it happens to land on. Even other zombies.  The jar is filled with the insides of a boomer, one of the special infected of the game.  The special infected of Left 4 Dead 2 are zombies with unique abilities that will prove deadly to survivors, and will require cooperation or a skilled shot to take down. Perhaps both..  The Boomer is a large zombie that vomits on survivors. This attracts the horde of generic zombies to attack them. However, if the survivors are not careful in dispatching the boomer, it will explode on death and splatter on the survivors, turning a situation from bad to worse.  The Hunter is a fast and agile zombie with a normal body frame, making it slightly harder to distinguish than other special infected when running. However, when it gets into a crouching position, it pounces on survivors and claws them until they die. It can pounce from very high locations to do extra damage, or it can ambush survivors from unexpected places. The Hunter wears a hoodie, and growls when getting ready to attack, screaming loudly when pouncing.  The Smoker is a tall zombie that coughs a lot. That's why you don't smoke, because then you'll get lungs like this guy. Anyways, the smoker has long reach, allowing it to pull survivors around, and into dangerous positions. Smokers will try to pull you into a car alarm to draw the horde to you, or they will try to pull you to another special infected so they can try to pick off another survivor, or maybe they'll just pull a survivor off a ledge, either getting them stuck holding it for their life, or forcing the victim to run all the way back to their group.  The Tank is a large, massive, and powerful zombie that can kill the entire group if left unchecked. They have huge muscles, which makes them an easy target, but it also represents their strength. One punch from a tank, and you'll fly several feet away from the rest of the survivors, and, on high difficulties, it could even end you in one hit. They can even toss rubble at the survivors, giving them a range option, as well as already being lethal in close quarters.  The Jockey is a small zombie, he runs fairly quickly and jumps on survivors, 'riding' them away into danger.  The Spitter is a taller type of special infected that spits acid onto survivors, being an effective long range unit that can deny an area to the survivors, or flush them out. Spitters also drop a pool of acid when they die, making them a bit more dangerous to deal with, especially when you are being pressured by a large amount of zombies.  The Charger is a large zombie that literally charges survivors. They run at the survivors with full speed and once they pick up a target, they continue running for a while, or until they hit something. This makes them very dangerous in situations where they can thrust you off of a dangerous height, or if there's deep water, because they can sacrifice themselves and take you with them.  Now, we've covered all of the special infected, and there's also uncommon infected as well, but I won't go over them here in order to save some space, and they aren't too important anyways.  The gunplay in Left 4 Dead 2 is very easy to get used to. From assault rifles, shotguns, pistols, melee weapons, snipers, and even grenade launchers, players should find it simple to point and shoot at zombies. Headshots are obviously more rewarding, as it will kill them zombie faster, and you'll save some ammo too. There are different deployable ammo types as well, which have different properties. High explosive, for example, will explode!  In Left 4 Dead 2, there are events in the game where you have to do something very loud in order to progress, but they draw a LOT of attention. These are called 'Crescendo Events'. These actions cause a massive attack from the infected, and require the survivors to defend themselves until the action is completed. Some events are gauntlet styled, which require survivors to run, rather than wait. Zombies will keep spawning in these gauntlet styled events, so it's best to move quickly. Also, at the jukebox, there's a song that plays and it says 'All we wanna do is eat your brains', which will also spawn enemies.  When a survivor dies, you can rescue them in closets through the game, or revive them with a defibrillator. However, you can rescue them before that and revive them when they are down. Going down too often without using first aid will result in death, which can be noted when the screen turns grey. Some game modes disable spawning, so it may be suited for super serious players.  At the end of every campaign, there is a final chapter, a finale. In the end, survivors hold out until rescue arrives, and this is the last stand for the campaign. Whoever dies here, is dead at the end, and at least one survivor must escape. Being prepared is extremely important here, as it will require determination from all survivors. Occasionally, the finale will also require the survivors run through another 'gauntlet' styled attack, except the finales are far more dangerous than the standard events, featuring more enemies and lots of special infected.  I recommend getting the game for CO-OP, it's great at what it does, which is being a great CO-OP experience.  For the single players, I honestly have trouble with recommending this game because there simply isn't enough to justify getting it just to play with the AI. The AI is extremely dumb, and they have HORRIBLE reaction times, occasionally letting you take massive amounts of damage before they save you, and not bothering to shoot the special infected, but instead they try to melee them when they are on you, making them waste valuable seconds needed to save your life. There's also not really a real story, other than backstories about the survivors and backstories about the other stuff around you. While some people have grown into the characters of L4D, I personally have not cared about any one of them enough to feel connected with the game itself. The soundtrack is also not really worth mentioning, in my opinion. It has a nice attempt at trying to place a dark feeling, but it's simply average at best. Gameplay also becomes monotonous without friends and workshop content, but you'll get a lot of replayability.

Left 4 Dead 2 is a multiplayer zombie FPS game, completely based on teamwork. Let's put this quick and short. You know how in most multiplayer zombie games, you can just leave your team and be the hero? Well, in Left 4 Dead, if you try that stunt, you WILL die. Your team needs to work together to make it through countless hordes of zombies, Special Infected, obstacles, and hardest of all, Tanks. The Special Infected include all the S.I. from the old game, plus three new ones: The Charger, the Spitter, and the Jockey. Here is a list of all the Special Infected and their abilities:  Hunter: Pounces on you and doesn't let go unless killed or shoved.  Boomer: Vomits on you and attracts zombies to you. Explodes vomit everywhere when killed.  Smoker: Constricts you with a long tongue and doesn't let go unless killed or you are shoved. Releases a cloud of smoke when killed.  Spitter: Spits acid at you that cause damage. Releases a pool of acid when killed.  The Jockey: Rides on your head and drags you sometimes into danger or more zombies. Does not let go unless killed or shoved off.  The Charger: Charges at you from a distance and pummels you into the ground. Doesn't let go unless killed.  Two major Special Infected include the Witch and the Tank:  The Witch: a crying Infected woman who, when provoked by either loud sounds, light, or proximity of survivors, will attack the provoker and any other Survivors after her provoker is dead. She can incapacitate or even kill a Survivor in one hit. The Witch was in the first game as well, but Left 4 Dead 2 introduces a variant of the Witch that wanders aimlessly in the open.  The Tank: a gigantic, extremely muscular Infected male with the strength to punch Survivors off their feet some distance, as well as toss cars and concrete slabs. Unless the Survivors work as a team, they will be quickly incapacitated or even killed by the Tank's inhuman strength.  Other enemies include normal zombies, Clowns, Hazmat Suits, Construction Workers, Mudmen, etc. The Story goes like this (This is going to be a lot of information so sit tight and read it all if you want):   The Sacrifice DLC campaign takes place before the main events of Left 4 Dead 2; and after the events of The Sacrifice comic. The original survivors of Left 4 Dead—Bill, Francis, Louis, and Zoey—arrive at the portside town of Rayford, in order to search for a boat that can take them to the Florida Keys. After finding an adequate sailboat, the Survivors have to manually start up generators in order to lift a bridge for their boat to pass through. One Survivor (canonically Bill) sacrifices himself in order to kick-start a generator once it gives out, so that the others may reach safety. This is the end of Bill's story in the Left 4 Dead video game series.    Left 4 Dead 2 opens in Dead Center (set in Savannah, Georgia), where the four Survivors find themselves abandoned on a hotel roof by rescue helicopters. They decide to head for the local mall, where a second CEDA evacuation point is located. After a brief encounter with a gun store owner, Whitaker (voiced by Dayton Callie), the Survivors discover that the mall is overrun, with all CEDA agents having become either dead or infected as well. Ellis helps the group use a stock car to bust out of the mall and travel towards New Orleans, rumored to be the last standing city in America.   The Passing DLC campaign takes place between Dead Center and Dark Carnival, and after the events of The Sacrifice campaign. The Survivors of L4D2 arrive at the bridge in Rayford, where they meet Francis, Louis, and Zoey. As they need to cross the bridge to proceed, the Survivors need to find another way across to refill the generator with gas. After fighting their way through a wedding reception (complete with a Witch bride), the streets, and a historic under-the-river tour, they meet up again with the original Survivors, who help by covering for the group while they fill the generator and lowering the bridge once it's full.   At the start of the Dark Carnival campaign, the four Survivors find the highway ahead completely blocked by ditched vehicles, and are forced to travel on foot through an abandoned (but still-operating) amusement park. After navigating their way to the park stadium, Coach devises a plan to use a large-scale light show used by a rock band, The Midnight Riders, in order to signal a helicopter pilot for rescue.   After being rescued, they later discover that their pilot has been Infected. When the pilot starts attacking them, Nick is forced to kill him (echoing a similar situation in the first game), causing the chopper to crash into a bayou, the setting for Swamp Fever. Working their way through the swamps, the group comes across a crashed airplane, dead military paratroopers, and isolated swamp villages which had held out against the Infected but were eventually overrun. After spending the morning fighting through the swamp, the group arrives at a plantation mansion and make radio contact with Virgil, a Cajun boat captain who can assist them; however, his boat begins to run low on diesel fuel on the way to New Orleans. As a tumultuous rainstorm approaches (the titular Hard Rain of the subsequent campaign), the Survivors go ashore at Ducatel, Mississippi; make their way through an abandoned (and Witch-infested) sugarcane mill to a gas station to get diesel fuel, and return to signal Virgil with an improvised 'flare'.   In the final campaign, The Parish, Virgil drops the group off at New Orleans, where the military appears to be evacuating civilians across a bridge. On the way there, the four discover the city overrun with Infected, and that the military is actually leaving the city before it is destroyed by an air strike. The group manages to reach the bridge, where they make contact with the military. Judging from their dialogue, the military pilots suspect the Survivors to be 'carriers', similar to the original Survivors of Left 4 Dead. After securing their rescue helicopter, the Survivors lower and cross the bridge, escaping on the helicopter just as the bridge is destroyed. While the Survivors' fate is left unclear after this point, Chet Faliszek, the game's writer, said that the military is taking survivors to cruise ships in the Caribbean in an attempt to escape the infection.  Left 4 Dead 2 comes with multiple modes to choose from. These modes are: Single Player, Multiplayer, Realism, Versus, Scavenge, Survival, and Mutation.  Single Player is your basic finish the campaign and survive. Nothing much more to say.  Multiplayer is the same thing, only with other players instead of bots.  Realism mode makes things harder, like no regeneration and the actual time of helping people up in a horde of zombies.  Versus is one team is the infected and the other team is the Survivors. The survivors have to go through the campaign without getting killed by the zombie players. The teams alternate everytime a safehouse is reached or the Survivors die.  Scavenge is similar to the Dead Center finale, where you have to fill up a take with gas cans. Only in this mode, its not just Dead Center, it's all the other campaigns as well. Just fill the tank with gas. Nothing more.  Survival gives you all the weapons and items, and forces you to try and survive against waves upon waves of zombies. The only objective is to see how far you can get.  All in all, with a fantastic storyline, great multiplayer, unsettling atmosphere, and so much variety, Left 4 Dead 2 lives up to its predecesor, and is a game that I recommend to everyone who enjoys playing with friends and shooting zombies in the face.

This review is a little lengthy, so if you just want to know why I recommend this game skip the  Results  and read from there.   Valve produces one of the most rigorous zombie games ever created. This fantastic first person shooter offers co-operative play which puts you right in the apocalypse that really keeps you on the run.    Story:  Left 4 Dead 2 places you as a character in a movie: Louis, Zoey, Francis, Bill, Coach, Ellis, Nick or Rochelle. Each level is suppose to be a part of a movie which combines into a single story. There are two stories which involve the first four characters or the latter. Eventually the characters from each movie integrate and intermingle joining the two movies together as one. There is a clear start and finish to the story, but as you play the maps online the story gets conveluded and lost. But if you play the campaign in order you will notice connections between all the maps that drive the characters to a set objective. Left 4 Dead 2 is a movie and as such the characters are unrealistically attributed with super human strength, unrealistic accuracy, and cheesy lines all of which are similar to most action movie stars.   Campaign:  Left 4 Dead 2 drops you right into a zombie apocalypse. The campaign consists of both Left 4 Dead 2 and remastered Left 4 Dead levels. The included campaigns are: No Mercy, Crash Course, Death Toll, Dead Air, Blood Harvest, The Sacrifice, Dead Center, The Passing, Dark Carnival, Swamp Fever, Hard Rain, The Parish, and Cold Stream. This can be expanded upon with hundreds of maps created using the editor which sometimes are better constructed than the originals. The brilliance behind this game is that due to a basic AI instructor the zombie placement changes every time you play a level which produces high replay value.   Modding:  Not only can you replay the included levels a plethora of times without being bored, but the workshop allows you to expand upon that and download new maps and mods that make the game better with every adjustment. You can even go to certain websites and download maps created by the community there. I personally prefer to download my maps from community websites as they are easier to install from the website. If you like fast paced zombie games and have some friends to play with this is the game for you.    Gameplay:  Left 4 Dead 2 is a fast paced Zombie first person shooter that involves running between areas to safe houses. Each level has chapters which you must run through, these chapters can either be incredibly long or ridiculously short. You have the choice to take it slow and work your way through the levels in time, or go as fast as you can. Typically teams that go slow do worst because as time progresses they must face more enemies than quicker teams. Hordes of fast moving zombies spawn in ways that can seem endless. Like most zombie games a headshot is much more effective than a chest shot, but enemies can still be taken down either way.    Multiplayer:  One of the epic features about this series is the online multiplayer. In this mode you are pitted as teams undead or survivors. The undead spawn as special zombies and must collaborate to kill off the survivors. Survivors on the other hand must complete objectives or finish chapters without all being perished. The multiplayer is brilliant, although it can be a little less fun if you don’t have someone to play with as this is a heavily team based game.    Results:  If you love zombie games, you like co-op experiences, you understand how to install mods, you just want to be an action hero, or even you just want to play by yourself Left 4 Dead 2 is the game for you. The amazing AI director makes the same map different every time. The bots although not the smartest can make a single player experience fun, and with some mods you can easily switch between players and control the bots if you accidently die. The game is an amazing action thriller that keeps you on your toes and constantly wanting more.   Pros: +Four player co-op campaigns that last at most one hour each +Good graphics and smooth animations +Fantastic zombie feel without seeming too mind-numbing (making zombies intelligent and tactful) +Fun campaigns that blow away realism and just create action packed fun. +Workshop compatible allowing for large amounts of mods and customization +Basic AI so you can play with a single friend without having to join a game online  Cons: -Mods are not perfect and can cause the game to crash (so remember what you installed before each play-through in order to remove defective files) -Bots are essentially mentally handicapped even with Bot Mods -Bots will not use the defibrillator unit -When playing single player the human player cannot switch between bots in order to continue enjoying the game despite their own demise -Some weapons seem excessive and worthless (two different types of pump shotguns) -Poor servers in comparison to the Xbox 360 (I miss mod free servers)

What I really liked about the game was how easy it was to become adjusted to the game as a beginner.   Of course, it is most recommended to play as single player or with friends when getting started. As I went through the game, it was neat picking on tips and tricks either learned by other players or things that worked best for me later on.   Special infected are as interesting as irritating, but it is all a part of the game and why it makes things fun.   The characters and plot are great. Everyone seems to have their favorite when playing these campaigns.  Some love and some hate these certain characters.   On the other hand, playing online is a completely different story. Some games go smoothly with little to no issues, while other times a single player can take down their own team or slow them down.  A con would have to be lagging depending on the internet/server.  Another con is that third party servers are irritating when going after achievements. If you're going for achievements, stay way from third party servers they make it harder depending on the group.  It is always important to keep in mind what your skill level as well as everyone else. Join a game/create a game that is best suited for you, joining a game that is out of your league or too easy may hinder your group.  Overall, the game is essentially about teamwork and how others bring out each other's strengths as well as weaknesses. It's a gamble everytime creating a lobby or joining someone's team to see if everyone will carry through to the end.   I highly recommend it, and I hope that this game is just as much fun for others as it has been for me. I apologize for any grammar errors, and thank you for taking the time to read it.

Ever since 2009 when the only gameplay platform I had was an Xbox 360, Left 4 Dead 2 has always been my favorite game to exist to this day. No game has ever captivated me in gameplay and atmosphere like Left 4 Dead as a series has. Left 4 Dead 2 holds so much signifigance, as it was my gateway into gaming itself. I do believe that without this game, I wouldn't be as into First-Person Shooters or Post-Apocalyptic games as I am now. It's amazing to see that a game I enjoyed back in 2009 is still going strong with a playerbase in 2016, and the game is certainly one of the best games Valve has ever created and Turtle Rock Studios has ever sparked.  Even though it is still going strong, it's a lie to say the game isn't dying. At it's prime, Left 4 Dead 2 had a 161,590 all-time peak (Not including console players), whereas games at it's time like Team Fortress 2 only reached a 110,000 all-time peak. It's very admirable and impressive, but Left 4 Dead 2's community is always steadily declining. However, the workshop has definitely kept a lot of players around, and me being an avid Versus player, I rarely ever run into the same person twice (probably 0.001% of games I've played have been with at most one person I've seen before, and that's only in the late-night hours).  Overall, the game is amazing. Even after 7 years, the game is still amazing and still impresses. If you currently don't own Left 4 Dead 2, you're missing out on gaming history.

Left 2 Die is a military shooter developed by Bethesda Games Studios and published by Electronic Arts. It's focused around a group of five highly trained military professionals and is known for its high degree of realism and gritty, immersive plot. Unfortunately, the game falls short of excellence for several reasons. First, the game does not let you use iron sights on any of the weapons. This detracts greatly from the realism of the game and makes complex tactics such as Run-And-Gun completely unviable. Second, there are no custom classes or leveling system. The lack of a ranking system, or 'Prestige,' means that there is no sense of fulfillment in the game. You cannot paint your guns different colours to make them distinct and realistic, nor can you unlock stronger weapons, forcing you to spend hours upon hours scavenging for supplies and usable equipment is a complete chore. Additionally, the game lacks prone and sprint mechanics. This is very unrealistic because you cannot lie on the ground and you cannot go fast enough to kill the baddies. Unfortunately, the game discourages teamwork, leaving players with almost no tactical options. This is suprising, considering that the developers at Treyarch have a long history of creating tactical masterpieces. The levels are poorly designed, with no objective other than to make it from staging room to staging room, it is disappointing that Square Enix decided to to develop a tactical modern military shooter with no other objective other than to survive against some deranged terrorist organisation. In spite of the games numerous flaws, the devs at Rovio have truly outdone themsleves in creating a modern masterpiece of storytelling. The narrative in Left 2 Die, the newest game from the renown developer Naughty Dog, is involving and profoundly emotional, moreso than their earlier titles such as 'littleBigPlanet' and the 'First of Them.' The five soldiers all have very unique personalities and the backstory is rich and enchanting. The ending is nothing short of sublime; without spoiling anything, Nintendo has managed to surpass the storytelling sucess seen in thir earlier title, 'Bioshock Infinite.'  The devs at NaVi have truly outdone themselves in their latest game, Left 2 Die. The title is sure to satisfy all types of gamers, from the casual to the hardcore trickshooters, and is literally flawless. Overall, i rate the latest DOTA 2 expansion pack, Left 2 Die, a 10/10, unforgettable.

I used to play this game all the time on my Xbox 360.  Then, I moved on to PC gaming around 2011, so I stopped playing it.  Then, in Christmas of 2013, they had the 'free download for a day' promotion. I waited literally hours for the store to stop having heavy traffic errors just so I could pick it back up. I eventually got it, installed it on my laptop, and played it a good bit before uninstalling it in early 2014.  Then, as of last October, I reinstalled it, and now I am back to playing it on a fairly regular basis like I did before 2011.  My point?  This game is a timeless classic. No matter how many times you play it, it is basically impossible for it to get old. Between the procedurally-generated waves of enemies, the countless amount of mods that are around that let you change the entire game into either a living nightmare or a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ circus, and so much more, this game will always be an absolute joy to play, especially with friends.  I do not know why I kept trying to get rid of this game. I am fairly certain that I will not be uninstalling it from this point forward, seeing as how I keep coming back to it for more after all these years. How do I even start when talking about Left 4 Dead 2?  So. Many. Game. Modes. Too. Many. Things. To. Do. I have about 40-50 something hours on this, as I am writing this review, and I haven't even played all the game modes, and don't even get me on the many mutation modes there are. Although this game overwhelms me with too many game modes, I can assure you that the modes I have played are truly, astounding.   Okay first off, I would like to point out that I play this on really, really low settings. I basically have anything that makes the game look good, turned all the way down. It's because I get a lot of lag. Anyways, the game still looks great. Amazing. The models don't look as nice as on higher settings, obviously, but it still looks great. Especially for a 2009 game. I really couldn't tell that much of a difference on the lower settings. The only thing I notice is how my game runs amazingly, even when there's five explosions going off at the same time.  Yes. The AI is incredibly stupid. It literally takes them ten minutes to kill special infected. But when they're not in trouble, they just go around aimbot and all, and steal all your kills. This isn't as annoying now, but it's still pretty annoying, like Rebecca Black. Most of the time though, you're playing with your friends and all, but warning to those who wish to play single player, DON'T, unless you are testing something.  Campaign: So there's lots of campaigns to complete. Including campaigns from Left 4 Dead 1 (if you wanna call it that...). I'm pretty sure I haven't even completed all the campaigns yet. So you play as 4 survivors, Coach, Rochelle, Nick, and Ellis. According to the opening scene, the people who were 'supposed' to rescue them left without them. So in the very first campaign with the 'new' survivors, you basically just try to survive to get to the last chapter in which you get rescued. Kind of... And that's basically the story line for everything. Now, although that sounds incredibly blan and boring, it's not. Yes. The story line is pretty linear, but the story doesn't even matter. The only thing that matters is the gameplay, and the funny remarks the survivors make throughout the campaign. Great fun, especially with your friends.  Mutation: Okay. So mutation is kind of like a special mode where special rules are applied. For instance, there is a mutation where the only weapon you can use is a chainsaw. So you go around with a chainsaw with unlimited 'ammo' so to speak, and slice zombies into pieces left and right. There are many more mutations, and I've only played a handful of them.  Versus: There's eight people who play in one server, 4 play as the normal survivors, trying to get through a normal campaign, the rest play as the infected. This is equally fun and rage inducing. I play this mode often. I think it's harder for the survivors to complete the mission in this mode. Just a little unbalanced, but it doesn't matter who wins when you're playing with your friends.  Scavenge: Now, I've only played this once or twice. From what I've played, you need to collect gas tanks to fuel a generator. It works in rounds, and is kind of a spin-off of versus, if you want to put it that way. There are two teams, one plays as infected, the other as survivors. The survivors collect as many tanks as possible. And when the timer for that round runs out, the team who were infected, now play as the survivors, and try to get more tanks than the other team. This mode is pretty fun, but I think I prefer regular versus better.   There are more modes, but I have either not played them, and/or do not want to go into SO much detail about the game. This is one of my favorite games on Steam. An amazing game from top to bottom. Graphics look good for an older game, physics are good (even though the shotguns are a little OP). Got this for free on the Steam Christmas sale, if you didn't, I wouldn't hesitate to pick this game up for 20 bucks. Overall, amazing game, with realistic features.  ~Krystal~

Game of the year! What a fantastic title to bestow upon a game that is deserving of the title. But what about game of the Decade?! So we all talk about 4K gaming, and all of this graphic intensive processing, faster machines, better performance, over-clocking and dinner at the local diner after a hard day at work. What most forget, however, are the emotions and experiences behind old video games, which don’t have all this fancy new technology being implemented into it, games that don’t have HD resolutions and frame buffering mechanics.   Now, Left for Dead 2. The predecessor of the original zombie first person shooter by valve, which caught the attention of millions of gamers worldwide. Left for Dead 2 is a zombie first person horror survival game. The game follows the story of four new hero’s, fighting their way through many infected human beings with the green flu. Unsure of how it started, but very obvious of the developing stages of “Zombies” such as the new special infected (Jockeys, Chargers, ect.)   The game itself is certainly an experience to have, with good physics, and even better zombie animations, you can shoot, smack and run away from the seemingly endless hordes of infected that come at you. Fight, survive, and help others who go down! But don’t let the whole team go down, or you’re in trouble!   Memories are certainly made with this game, and for a video game that is four and half years old, it’s impressive how much detail and effort has gone into this game.   Fight, survive, and get to the chopper!   I absolutely recommend this game. And if you don’t want to buy it, wait for the major holiday sale! It goes up for free!  Played 80 hours+ And many more are to come.

Left 4 Dead 2, Valves own take on the zombie survival genre. It is superior to its previous installment as it includes additional campaigns featuring said characters but otherwise gameplay wise is similar. The game is a first person shooter with co-op focus where the objective is to survive from point A to point B navigating creative levels and hordes of zombies. The game is best experienced in multiplayer format as the friendly AI is rather useless, and it adds much to the experience playing with players. There is a moderate variety of missions and gamemodes with some special modes and custom maps adding additional interest to the title once you grow tired of the core campaign. Versus mode is also a great treat, whereby two teams take turns playing as the survivors and the 'special infected' (strong specialized zombies), this mode is challenging and will keep players coming back for more. It has something for both single player and multiplayer gamers, although the experience is heavily multiplayer biased. Overall this game is a popular title with solid gameplay, it gets a full recommendation.

I haven't played much scavenge but it's OK. Mutations would be cool if people actually played them. Realism is a good challenge, especially on Expert Realism. Realism versus is almost a rebalancing of versus but in my experience, it favours the infected. This game is best played with friends, as there is griefing and trash talking. You can turn off voice chat and all that, but that messes up communication, so you're best off kicking them or leaving (most of the time).  This game is seven years old and still has a pretty decent player base, take that as you will. It has had a few Free Weekends and even on one weekend, it was free to permanently keep. Just don't play versus when you start off. Play campaign and then you can apply that knowledge to versus. If you go straight into versus, expect trash talking and kicks A LOT; the L4D2 community is not forgiving to noobs. Even if you've played campaign a fair amount, you will still find versus quite difficult to get into, as you have to figure out and learn the chokepoints and metastrategy (general strategy - knowing how to adapt, when to attack etc.). L4D2 versus players, for the most part, won't hold your hand. Unfortunately there's no noob servers so you either have to just keep playing and deal with the (not THAT many) kicks or go on YouTube for help. Generally speaking, you're better off by starting to do do some campaign to nail down the basics and get some intermediate knowledge (which you can then apply to versus) and look up some YouTube videos about how the infected work.  I would recommend this to those looking for a fun, casual game that has (some) depth to it. It's a linear game so don't expect that much depth, but the teamwork and coordination required, in the higher difficulties and even against good versus teams, cannot be understated. The gameplay is satisfying, the game runs on a toaster and is very well optimized. It's cheap, on sales at least. If you still haven't played this game and you enjoy zombie games, you really shouldn't pass up on this one.

The Jockey, is one of irritating special infected because of its ability to 'ride' survivors and lead them to another path. The Spitter is one of the best special infected, because of its power to spit acid it is useful to infected that pins down survivors, for example: If a smoker was killing a survivor but the survivor's buddies are heading its way the spitter can spit its acid and do MASSIVE damage enough to kill the survivor quick before its buddies reach the corpse. Left 4 Dead 2 is the sequel to Right 2 Alive, a game that no one asked for or liked. In this game, you and up to 3 friends/coworkers you feel pressured to do something with/random people on the internet (one of whom is probably a serial ♥♥♥♥♥♥) can experience all the fun of attempting teamwork for about five minutes, then having someone run ahead of everyone else the second more reanimated corpses (AKA Grateful Dead fans) than can be easily dealt with appear, leaving the rest of the team for dead.   Hence the name.   A former football coach who desperately yearns for cheeseburgers, a rich ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ whose fancy suit stays relatively clean throughout the game, a good ol' country boy who is slightly not smart, and the strangest of all, a girl, band together in an attempt to reach New Orleans, where an evac center is located, in the wake of a worldwide epidemic that turned many people dead and then undead. The base game is divided into 5 chapters, which are further split into around 5 sections, in which the goal is to get from safehouse to safehouse, which are enclosed spaces where the dead people can't eat your face.    Miraculously, all of the characters became expert marksmen the day that ♥♥♥♥ hit the fan, enabling them (which, by way of video game logic, enables you) to use a not incredibly wide variety of firearms that are handy for making the undead redead. They are also all able to bench press a formidable amount of weight, seeing as they/you can also use some melee weapons, ranging from baseball bats and axes to guitars and cricket bats, to detach formerly alive people's heads from their torsos. By killing a metric ♥♥♥♥ton of zombies, performing the occasional lever pull or button press, doing some assorted tasks, and not letting your squad get eated, you make it to the next safehouse. And your reward? More zombies, more levers and buttons, more assorted tasks, and more safehouses, along with more opportunities to get a leg up on your teammates and zip halfway across the map before getting bogged down by the infected, and then whine about how you weren't saved by your teammates when they were barely out of the safehouse door. Fun!   There are some special snowflakes amongst the reanimated crowd that make your team's lives far less pleasant. These include a midget that rides you like an epileptic horse, a fat guy who is in dire need of some Pepto Bismol, some girl with a really long neck that ejects acid from her mouth, a dude who has one disproportionately large arm on account of whacking it too hard who slams you into crap, and some guy with a really long tongue that smoked too much back when he was a regular person. There are also crying girls that flip out at your attempts to comfort them, and a cousin of the guy who whacked it too hard that is on an alarmingly large amount of performance-enhancing drugs (he was probably a former baseball player). If you spot them before they can do too much damage and take them out relatively quickly, they really aren't that big of a deal, but rest assured, at least one of your teammates will find a way to get killed by them and yell at you for not saving them.    Along with the main co-op campaign, there are also several other modes to play, the most interesting of which being Versus. In Versus, you either play as one of the dudes from the campaign or get put on a team of the aforementioned special snowflakes. As a dude from the campaign, you have to make it to the end of one of the campaign levels. As a special snowflake, your job is to simply be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to the campaign dudes and see that they don't make it to the end of the level by using your special snowflake powers. It's a fun addition to a game that would already be great.   In conclusion, if you don't already have this game, it would be advisable to pony up the $20, grab some friends, and then scream at them for being dumb/ leaving you for dead. The zombie killing is fun and gory (though the zombies feel a little paper-thin) and working as a team feels great during the 1% of the time where everyone actually works as a team. This game also includes a sixth chapter, as well as all the chapters from the first game, rendering the first installment obsolete.    Lastly, if none of that convinced you to get this, there is a mod that turns the tank into Shrek.   9/10. Buy it, you weiner.

L4D2 is no doubt on of the best zombie games ever. It is a co-op focused game where 4 players have to run through waves of zombies in order to get to the safe zone located on the other end of the map and eventually escape the area. The game also has other multiplayer modes like Versus, Survival and a few others.  Every campaign in L4D2 can be played online or singleplayer with bots. These campaigns have multiple stages that can be played individualy. The story told throughout the campaigns is very simple and nothing worth bothering about. The game as plenty of weapons both firearms and melee weapons that are all very fun to use. The Source Engine once again creates a nice looking game with it's own slow-aging and pretty graphic style.  This being a Source game, it has a lot of community-created content that you can find in the Workshop. You can get anything from there: a Bin Laden skin for the Witch, Minecraft zombie skins, the Helm's Deep map, you name it!  Even though the game is focused on the online co-op, I played the whole thing with bots and I never felt like I was missing out on anything or like I had a disadvantage. The bots are actually great, they always revive you, they are very good at shooting, they will heal you when you need it, they can use any weapon, they call out special zombies... So you can play alone if you want. My favorite multiplayer mode is by far the Versus mode where a team of player-controlled special zombies tries to stop the survivor's team. The other modes are OK but nothing special. The biggest flaw of this game (in my opinion) is really the fact that the co-op is way too simple and can be played with bots. I much prefer a more complicated co-op game like Payday 2 where you really have to employ some teamwork if you want to survive. L4D2 is just run and gun and expect your teammates to not be super ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥...or play with bots, they never fail.  If you just want to kill some zombies, this is a great game. If you want to do that with friends, it's also a great experience. If you're looking for the best co-op game in the market, there are far better games that this one. Left 4 Dead has been a part of my life since the day it came out, and I fell in love with it the minute I made my first kill. There's so much timeless fun and enjoyment to be found within the series, such a high replay value and intense, gripping action that begins right from the start, up until the bloody end. Very bloody. With a few limbs lying around. Some heads here and there as well.  One of the absolute best parts of Left 4 Dead 2 (and the first one too, really) is the community. Of course, as with any community, one is most certainly bound to encounter a bad apple or ten, but that's to be expected if they have experienced online gaming before. The good definitely outweighs the ugly, though, as the community is the very heartbeat which keeps this game alive to this day. With new, mostly superb mods coming out all the time, different fun ways to play and new, goofy things to mess around with, different character models, all-new weapons and so, incredibly much more, players are always finding amazing ways to keep our beloved franchise thriving. There is also a great deal of hilarity that will ensue at certain times which only makes the game that much better.  It's not often I can say this about a modern game- while I do enjoy a great deal of them - but this is a sheer instant classic that I urge everybody to try at least once, even if they wind up disliking it in the end.

While I'm not usually one for zombie games and that whole phenomenon, I don't get a negative vibe at all when playing this game. It's an excellent cooperative game that puts teamwork above all. There is a relatively vast array of weapons to choose from. (The chainsaw is very fun to use.) The characters each have their own unique personas and, by holding down X, you can choose emotions for them. It simply makes them say sassy things (don't even get me started about Rochelle). There is Versus mode, where you actually get to play as the zombies and the other team (Versus is 4v4) plays as the survivors, and it switches off. Survival mode is the classic and arguably most exciting mode. In this mode, you simply fight waves and waves of zombies until you die, and despite sometimes (no, often) getting frustrated, you will want to keep retrying and rethinking your strategy to effectively fight the zombies while keeping your teammates alive. The L4D1 maps are included and their characters are playable for those specific maps. Excellent game.

This game is amazing. Single and multi-player are very neat and the story too, which I didn't really expect.  There are some minor things that bug me some times. L4D2's A.I. is pretty wonky and unreliable sometimes. This considers your co-op partners as A.I.'s, but also the monsters(/zombies). The A.I. of the Boomer, for example, could be a lot sneakier, making it more of a challenge towards players.  As for your 'partners', even though they don't do damage to you (or shouldn't), it too often occurs they hit you and you kind of flinch. Or they stand in your way (by accident?).  Besides all of that, the game is very fluent. The way you walk, the action, the storyline and even the surroundings. The environment throughout the storyline keeps changing, keeping the player's interest. The A.I.'s are pretty decent, the enemies have nice designs, every category has their own special abilities, making every zombie special in their own way. I especially like it that you have the ability to also hit enemies off of you when they're close, say when you need to reload or don't have the correct weapon/item selected yet. The hit pushes them back, giving you some time.  As for multiplayer the difficulty level seems to raise a bunch, because now you do have smart, thinking opponents, being able to be all sneaky. So if you want a challenge, a very difficult challenge at that, then I would suggest you start multiplayer immediately :)  Be it single player, Co-Op, multiplayer... Always try to stick together and have fun, because it is a very enjoyable, dynamic and fun game to play.  There is so much more I could say about this game, but I'll keep it at this. Hope you enjoy.

Score: 9/10  Left 4 Dead 2 takes all of the aspects of the original Left 4 Dead that we all know and love and improves upon them. The singleplayer/co-op campaign mode is incredible, and you'll find yourself starting to get more and more into the story as the game progressess. There are many maps with multiple different subzones in each, giving the world quite a large feel. The AI is, for the most part, pretty damn good, and works well for both the infected and survivors. The combat is very simple and comfortable, and is a hell of a lot of fun. Other than the co-op, the main reason for playing L4D2 is the multiplayer. You play through the same maps as you do in the campaign, but with the twist of one team controlling the special infected. This may seem like a clunky idea at first, but in practice is one of the most enjoyable multiplayer modes I've ever played. It's so simple, but at the same time there can be a lot of strategy from both teams to try and secure the win. Playing as the survivors against infected controlled by other players gives you a feeling of being hunted, expecting them to be around every corner or lurking in the dark behind you at all times. At the same time, playing as the infected is my personal favorite aspect of the game. You feel like a hunter chasing your prey, and when you manage to pull off a good attack, it is very rewarding.   The amount of content in this game is huge, with both the maps from the original game as well as the new ones, in addition to user-created content on the Steam Workshop. There is just so much to do in this game, and I love every bit of it. There's just endless replayability, and age hasn't hurt this game in the least. If you want a zombie game that you can put a lot of hours into, and have a great time solo or with friends, this is the one for you.

Left 4 Dead 2 by Valve brings some new gameplay elements into the post-apocolyptic Infected slaying. Four new survivors: Coach, Nick, Ellis and Rochelle. And three new infected: The Charger, which charges into your team, capable of knocking them all down and grabbing one of the survivors, slamming it repeatedly into the ground. The Spitter, which spits acid goo from her deformed mouth, which, in the beginning is not that harmful, but is capable of decapicating survivors in mere seconds. When she dies, she leaves a puddle of her acid goo around her body. Also the Jockey, a small infected cackling like a madman and jumping onto a survivor's back and steering them into danger. It also includes a female model of the Boomer, a new version of the Witch, the Wandering Witch, which (no pun intended) is less dangerous than the sitting Witch, as she is easier to avoid. All new Uncommon Infected, CEDA workers, which wear hazmat suits, are immume to fire and potentially drop Boomer Biles (a new throwable, which send Common- and Uncommon Infected at a certain location and even other Infected). The Worker Infected, which isn't attracted by the pipe bombs. The fallen Survivor, which drops a molotov cocktail and a med-kit. The Clown Infected, which draws other Infected near him, with the noise of his squeaky shoes. The Mudmen, which can blur your vision with mud. And the Riot Infected, which can only be killed by an attack from the back.  Furthermore, it adds melee weapons, which are very handy for crowd control and brand-new Mutations. Which bring all new game modes to Left 4 Dead 2. And last, but not least, it's compatible with the Steam Workshop.

I wasn't used to zombies and fps in general (or maybe some cs from time to time) but Left 4 Dead 2 is something. The mechanisms are basic but yet this game has something special that other games don't.   As a survivor, you have a large panel of weapons to rip off your enemies, going for the Chrome Shotgun (<3) to the almighty Grenade Launcher (<3) and I'm not forgetting the Melee weapons which, in my opinion, are the infected's deadliest foes (beating a hunter with a Frying Pan is such an '♥♥♥♥♥♥'). You may also use consumables such as a Molotov to take care of hordes of zombies or to set a tank on fire, or an adrenaline shot to get some extra health and action speed. The most important thing in this side is the teamwork : you always need to know where your mates are and be ready to save them as soon as they are in trouble (so should they). Indeed, in versus, the infected also work together to deal you as much damages as possible in synchronized attacks.  In conclusion, the key to the survivor's success is : Team Spirit. If you don't have it, you won't win.  As an infected, you may play as different kind of specials : Hunter, Jockey, Charger, Smoker, Spitter, Boomer or Tank. Each of them have specificities but I won't go into details as it would require a lot of time to explain. Anyway, the infected share the same point of view as the survivor. Your goal ? Kill them. You must use your environments and the abilities of your mates together in order to deal damages to their team and ultimately, defeat them. A regular strategy is to get a lone survivor while other infected cover him by distracting the others. Another, more common to experimented players, is to set up a 2, 3 or 4man strat in order to INSTANTLY kill a survivor (death charge in No mercy's finale). Anyway, remember that the teamwork is the way to succeed. Think carefully, act decisively. The other team won't let you beat them that easely.  Due to some prices drop, more new players buy the game. That's a good thing. The problem is that they want to get straight into the really challenging content (which is versus). Please, listen. Even if you have been playing fps for years, even if you have beated Garrosh Hellscream in Heroic before the nerf (World of Warcraft), if you are new to this game then you should (= MUST) go to campaigns first. This way, you'll start being familiar with l4d2 : bashing, aiming, infected abilities, events, etc. I suggest playing at least 100 hours in campaigns, asking the more experimented players for advices, reading some guides. Versus isn't a playground. I, to be honest, hate being confronted with those newborn survivors who do not know the words 'Synchronized' or 'Team Spirit', who are just leaving their mates behind, who are attacking brainlessly. No. Please, Versus remains some serious business. Of course you can have fun in there, I do and I enjoy playing with different players, but you NEED some experience before going into that battlefield where the other team won't let you get a rest and rip you off like Peanut Butter Jelly bread.  *cough* I sounded kind of harsh there but back to the point. Left 4 Dead 2 is a really enjoyable game. You get to know new people. The mods are original (unlimited ammo on M60, yay !) and you may wander in the workshop for some cool stuff (such as having Ellie's model - The Last of Us - instead of Zoey or new weapons skin). I recommend this game to every player who likes the thrill of the fight. As a finisher, remember these words : Have fun, Have the Team Spirit.   See you in l4d2 !

Left 4 Dead 2 is a Coop zombie shooter released by Valve. It features new maps and a new cast, along with new specials and weapons; this all blends to make an incredible game to play with your friends. The campaigns are all well made, and the game is just a ton of fun to play with friends in campaign; however, be warned that the versus aspect of it may be very offputting. In versus you take control as survivors and infected, taking turns to make more points and win. Unfortunately many people who play this mode are bad, and as a result it can be frustrating to find a good match. Another problem is that actually learning versus. Naturally one should play the campaign to learn the maps, but this isn't enough. Learning good spots as infected, knowing the best pace, etc. Many of these tactics aren't necessary to beat campaign, and usually only help in versus. And when a player doesn't know these things the player will probably get kicked very quickly. Learning the game is hard enough with enemy teams that are usually stacked well with veterans, but when you're also watching for kicks it only makes it worse. However, if you can keep at it WITH FRIENDS, the versus can be enjoyable and good fun. Overall though, the strong and very enjoyable campaigns and survival make up for versus' varying degrees of enjoyability. It's only $20, and it will be well spent.

Since I'm approaching the 1000 hours, something that's never happened to me with any other game, I thought i'd write a review.  Left 4 Dead 2 is one of the games with gameplay that is suprisingly simple, but can be very difficult to master. Fun for beginners and pros, but only when the teams are balanced. Since it's all about teamplay, there's little fun to be had if a team of pros combats a team of beginners. You will simply get ♥♥♥♥♥, no matter how good you think you are at FPS games. That's why i advise people to play with similarly experienced players. When L4d3 comes out Valve should definitely implement such a match making system.   Anyway, when you play this game long enough you'll find out that it's more about strategic positioning rather than skillful shooting. Stay close to your team as a survivor and look behind you from time to time. As an infected it's a MUST to know the qualities of your character and to work together with the other players. All of them have their specific strengths in certain situations. Typically, you want to start with disorienting the survivors with a boomer, then to charge in them and let the spitter and smoker finish it up. But since the combinations differ every spawn and the levels are varied there are not any written rules about how to play. The only thing that will help is to memorize the different parts in each level that provide good attacking opportunities and coordinate them with your team. It takes a lot of time and it is also the reason why you can still feel like a noob after spending 100 hours in this game.  Don't let this scare you away though. It is still a lot of fun regardless of your experience. The only annoyances you will face is that people tend to rage quickly once they get beaten too hard. And since there is no penalty for leaving a game, campaigns often end with completely different teams than the ones that they started with. Again something that should be looked into if they are going to make another sequel. On the other hand the way things are now prevent the game from becoming really serious, which is also something I like.

95%  Being a huge fan of zombies and a huge fan of the original Left 4 Dead, I couldn't wait to get my hands on this baby. The amount of different types of game can be staggering (single player, offline CO-OP, campaign, scavenge and survival) but there's enough in there so that if you don't like all of it, you'll still find enough to do to keep the interest.  The characters in the original L4D were all well and good, and I've heard some people moan about how they didn't like the way these new characters; Nick, Rochelle, Ellis and Coach, didn't seem to get on. This isn't exactly true - the more you play the game, the more new dialogue you're presented with showing the characters' relationships to one another. Nick has issues with Ellis, who occasionally takes a shot back at Nick, but Ellis gets on great with Coach, who treats Rochelle like a little sister, who is almost flirtatious with Nick. They're really interesting, funny characters with much better voice acting than the first, and I personally can't get enough of them.  The campaigns in the game are linked by a lightweight story of the four trying to get from A to B to be rescued. Do not hold any misconceptions about L4D2 - there's not meant to be a backstory. The goings on and character build up are cleverly presented to you in the world around you; all you have to do is simply look. Read the graffiti. Listen to the characters, it's all there. It's a zombie apocalypse, what more do you need?   I think the only problem I've had is the people online that I've come across. There are some real idiots on the versus/scavenge games who take things far, far too seriously. In this case, I would find friends to play with, or go on a forum where you can meet decent people before you add them.  Even if you haven't played the first, it's a fun, intense, gory, silly game that will make you laugh, jump, freak out and have a great time. Especially if you find a frying pan.

The game is enjoyable by itself in solo mode for a few hours. Once all maps have been completed, you need to get to know the maps by heart. Versus game mode provides the best experience: after more than 1000 hours I still enjoy building teamplay. After a while, you'll seek for the perfect attack as a Zombie, or as the perfect run as a survivor.  That seek for perfection makes the game enjoyable on the long term.  Also, the game's IA sends waves of zombies, of tanks and other pleasant creatures, depending on your level, and the one of your team.

As of November 2015, this is the single greatest multiplayer team versus-style game on the market. Yes, its been years since it's release, and its still the best. It also has a really fun co-op mode but what keeps me coming back is the 4v4 infected versus humans mode.  The gameplay can be taken to varying levels of depth depending on what you and your friends want out of the game. If you want a more casual experience, the game can provide that. If you want a more competitive experience, the game can provide that too. The game can also be tweaked with mods or custom servers. I believe it is a bit of a necessity, as the game's default settings, while fine, are not optimal for either fun or competition. That is the one drawback of this game: in order for it to have the same staying power for you as it does for me you will need to tweak it to your desires. Fortunately the Steam Workshop integration makes this easy in a lot of ways, and there are thousands of cool mods for this game that are very simple to install. Setting up a custom server on the other hand can be difficult and that is really the only way to tweak the gameplay itself, but it is well worth the effort if you have a group of friends you consistently play with.   Let's talk about that gameplay for a second. This is a FPS game (though it can be easily modded to be a TPS) with a few important caveats. Firstly, most of the infected classes can grab you and will kill you unless you're saved by a team mate. Short of a couple rare ploys, there is no way to save yourself! This is a team game and you must stick together for the most part. Second, in addition to guns the humans are given a certain number of melee shoves that recharge over a short period of time. The shoves keep the infected players and the AI zombies at bay quite effectively. The gameplay can either be glossed over so you can just focus on having fun, or you can go as deep as you want, really. The moves of the humans and also the infected players can be optimized to an insane degree. The difference between watching two casual teams and two skilled competitive teams is like watching two entirely different video games. I cannot stress this enough that the learning curve can go as deep as you're capable of taking it. There are many competive communities (most of which boast their own slew of modifications and tweaks to gameplay) and all that I've seen are willing to accept new players.   There are tons of custom maps for this game too! A myriad of fan-made tributes to various other games and works of literature. Want to play through Dark Tower: Gunslinger in a zombie game? Theres a custom campaign for that. Want to play through Resident Evil Outbreak? Theres a custom campaign for that. Want to play through a zombified Legend of Zelda forest puzzle map, or an undead homage to the Portal series, or an amazingly well-made recreation of Shadow Moses from Metal Gear Solid 1? There are custom campaigns for that! The modding community for this game is massive and not to be overlooked.  This is one of the best games, maybe THE best game I've ever owned, in terms of replay value and entertainment. I paid ten dollars for it and got years of great fun (I gladly would have paid 100 dollars for this game). You need friends to play with though, so this game isn't for everyone, but if you have enough fun people to play with then this game is incredible. My hat is off to the developer and I also took some other people's hats off because mine alone was not enough.
