Left for dead 2 Is a great Team based First Person Shooter. The point of this game is plainly -- Get from point A to point B without dying. But it's not so simple. Your biggest help and biggest burden is usually your team. For this game to be fun you almost NEED a team of like minded players. Wether your just going through one of the campaign 'movies' for giggles and guts or youre attempting to play on the hardest difficulty, the expierience falls apart if you get someone who is too serious or not serious enough. Once an arguement breaks out your entire team has lost hope (usually). Thats why I only really play with my friends or computer players. So, if you can get a good team together this game is a blast.    Some campaigns can be a walkthrough, some an be a mile thorugh hell, and others still can have the wackiest stuff happen. With over 10 campaigns that change slighty(drop points, special infected spawns) with each playthrough it is going to be a while before you get bored with this title. The graphics are quite good as well and like with all source games, its heavily optimized and can be played on nearly any machine. Sometimes theres a little slowdown here and there on my laptop but it never drops below 20fps on the lowest settings. Crispy graphics make the blood and gore, and sometimes dismemberment, rather satisfying.   The number of wapons available to create such gore is nice and varied. Theres no two guns that do the exact same thing. You have your tier1 weapons and tier 2 weapons. I believe its at least 10+ guns available and a handful of meele weapons too, including a very shaun-of-the-dead cricket bat.    I must concede though after playing through the campaigns a few times it can get a little boring if you only play on the easiest difficulties. The randomness of friends and drops keeps things fresh for a bit, but between my career on the xbox and steam, I have trouble getting my friends to play L4D2 simply because of lack of campaigns. They do have the steam workshop for new campaigns, and it works 90% of the time, but the process of getting everyone in your party to find,download, and finding a server for the user created campaigns is somewhat daunting if you dont know what youre doing. Some of the Workshop maps are fun and inventive, others are just pandemonium. It really comes down to taste a that point. I prefer the official campaigns.    I Loved l4D2 and I still do. I just have it shelved at the moment because I guess I overplayed it. If you enjoy either FPS games or zombies at all this is a must play. If you like story-driven narritive, this is not for you. The narritive in the campaigns is weak, and not important at all to gameplay. This is good, bloody, mindless, zombie killin' fun.

I am not a huge fan of zombie shooters, but Left 4 Dead 2 is quite the exception. This is because unlike most zombie shooters, the game is not focused on blowing the heads off zombies 'for the lulz'. Behind the ordinary FPS-style gameplay you'd expect in the typical zombie massacre game, a great deal of cooperation and teamwork is required for survival. Chances are in a normal campaign map, you won't last 5 minutes on your own. You must work with and rely on your fellow teammates in order to survive. Besides gameplay, the story and characters play a big role in the overall experience. In L4D2, you become extremely involved with the survivors, perhaps even connected with them, not to mention the apocalyptic world around you. Even though there is not much backstory, The world around you literally speaks for itself. Along with the playable survivors, you learn of the struggles and fates of hundreds of unseen survivors fighting for their lives. In other words, the world around you is very believable for an apocalyptic pandemic. When government and society crumbles around the survivors, they are simply left to fend for themselves. To make this short and sweet, the high level of cooperation-based shooting, interesting and diverse group of survivors, and the compelling apocalyptic word around you, are just a few things that make this a unique and entertaining rollercoaster ride of a game.

This is a soley teamwork related game with many gamemods to choose from and an AI Director that keeps making random experences everytime and special infected that require a team to fend off this game couldn't get any better I could explain in detail all the gamemods but here are the basics  Campaign- This gamemode pits you against AI hordes and special infected with human controlled team mates which requires close teamwork to survive each finale from holding out to collecting gas to even running across a bridge thats being bombed by the military  Single player- Nothing much to say about this game mode its the normal campaign but instead of humans its offline bots  Versus- In Versus you are pitted against swarms of common infected while fending off human controlled specials each team takes turns playing as humans and infected with these playable infected and non playable infected: The Smoker- He will drag survivors with a long tounge towards him and will repeatidly bash them untill their team mates free them or they die if he can not directly drag them to him he will constrict them where they are stuck. The Boomer- Nothing much to explain about him he is a bloated infected who will throw up boomer bile on the survivors attracting a horde to attack them and attractting nearby infected if killed he will explode showering bile on nearby surfaces and survivors their is an item that allows the survivors to use his own bile against him. The Hunter- A hooded teenage looking infected who will leap great distances to catch lone survivors dealling massive damage untill killed or freed can leap from far and high places to deal damage pounces which range around 1 to 25 damage dealling instant damage and is the only infected that does not have to wait for his ability to recharge. The Charger- This infected has a large arm that will smash into survivors knocking other team mates into the air he cannot be bashed off his victim normally having to be killed a Charger may also ram survivors off high places incapping or killing instantly. The Jockey- The Jockey is the only infected that can move their victim around willingly instead of the Chargers ram which cannot be steered as well as the Smokers pull and Hunters pounce The Jockey can be fought against though if the survivor mashs their move buttons making it difficult for the Jockey to move them but they also deal damage much like the others clawing at their victims face untill downed and unable to ride like the Hunter it must pounce to capture someone. The Spitter- Purely a support infected like the Boomer the Spitter can split survivors with her acid spit or can spit on incapped or 'pinned' survivors spreading panic and killing the survivor quicker making it a valuable asset to the team if used correctly like the Boomer its death has a last act of revenge spreading its acid although smaller on the ground like its spit attack. The Tank- The Tanks the brute force and favorite of most players the Tanks only goal is to spread damage to kill or make a miserable mess of the survivors defences with 3 different attacks like its punch attack which knocks back survivors knocking them senseless for a short amount of time a rock throw attack taking out snipers who aren't willing to take any damage from the behemoth and knocking them down giving the Tank a chance to get close and a car/object punch which sends any car or object flying and immediatly incapping survivors or on rare chances stumbling them or killing them making it very effective at taking out close groups and clusters. The Witch- The Witch is one of the only infected thats avoidable only attacking when disturbed killing and incapping in one hit being startled by flashlights and close survivors.  Realism and Realism Versus- Realism is a gamemode of pure teamwork being unable to see someone through walls or being pinned also Witches will kill in one hit Realism Versus is purely the same as Versus defualt just with the added rules of Realism.  Survival- Much like the Call of Duty gamemode Zombies but with a twist the survivors are able to equip anything they like before they start the match and instead of rounds its random hordes and Tanks as well as a timer recording how long your team survived 2 alteritive Mutations( We will get to these) are Survival Versus which is Survival with Versus merged and one team sets the time while the other beats it and keeps going till one team does not beat the others time and Hold Out which is like a Hold Out finale but quicker to finish.  Scavenge- A quick version of Versus one team must collect gas cans and put them in the generator while the infected team must try and stop them from beating their score the first team to beat their score all added together wins the match.  Mutations- Weekly gamemodes like Hunting Party, Last Man On Earth and TAAAANK! that are available on the Steam Workshop along with other community made skins and Campaigns that are remixes of gamemodes or entirely new ones as earlier mentioned Survival Versus is one such gamemode.  Now for the conclusion this game has its ups and downs like its prequel but its worth buying the glitchier but funner version on P.C with the custom content and free DLC some players do not like the lack of weapons while most like it cause its simple and means your favorite weapons never too far from reach but what about the gamemodes? are some even worth playing? It is true that Survival and Scavenge are not played as much like Mutations mostly cause most players normally have enough time on their hands to play a full Campaign or Versus match and most of the Mutations that are fun require manual installation or having to be found in the wasteland of the Steam Workshop but this does not mean its not a bad game I rate it 9/10 Cause of its teamwork based gameplay which I have yet to see in many games and plus Valves style of simplicity with simple graphics and not overly complicated gameplayer (I am looking at you Battlefield and Call of Duty) this games a hit and miss some people will like it some will not but I absolutely love it as I have played the first since it came out and loved that even though I was missing alot such as weapons and items and lacking infected varity but its simplistic gameplay style contributes to it so thats my review and have a great day!

At first, the game is baffling. There is nothing to do (except Steam achievements), nothing to unlock, nothing to gain. Okay, I understand this is not a RPG. But there is a more grievous point: no record of what you have done. For the solo campaign for example, I have to write down, using pencil and paper, what campaigns I finished ! That would be acceptable for retrogaming but this is lame for a modern video game.  After some research, I found out that Steam records your survival times. Okay, but outside the game ! Talk about a clumsy user-interface.  Outwardly, there are many game modes. In fact there are only two: * Player vs player. As there is no ranking, PvP is not attractive. Noobs are stomped by vets and this is not fun. (Granted, this is also true for TF2 or World of Tanks, but these games offer a more developed PvP experience.) Also the L4D2 community is the most toxic I have ever seen for a casual game. Stay away. * Solo or coop vs bot. Game experience is intense. Content is big. But game is highly repetitive. Diversity of weapons does not save the day.  So why a positive review ? Despite its big flaws, L4D2 offers a unique game experience. Creepy, gore, intense. It is so fun to explode zombies with a shotgun ! A worthy classical Valve game worth buying during Steam sales.

While Left 4 Dead 2 had a rocky start, Valve greatly improved the quality of the game after release. In almost every way L4D2 replicates it's predecessor and surpasses it at the same time.   L4D2 unlike it's predecessor has maps that take place during the day. It features more special infected that require constant movement and cover. And it features melee weapons that add an entirely new dynamic to gameplay. All of these features are woven very well with the carried over elements from L4D1. The game still requires players stick together inorder to avoid being pounced by legions of undead and it keeps the frantic fast paced atmosphere. Alongside that, the game's versus mode adds a great deal of strategy to the gameplay. And lastly it's survival mode allows players to test their skills and provide a nice healthy amount of competition amongst each other.   I'd go as far as to say L4D2 now is one of Valve's best attempts at multiplayer games on the Source engine. Harder, Faster, Better and Stronger in almost every way.10 of 10!

I could not decide what to write in this review so.. here is a recipe for chicken and broccoli stir-fry.  ingredients 1/2 cup water 2 tablespoons soy sauce 2 tablespoons hoisin sauce 2 teaspoons cornstarch 1 teaspoon grated fresh ginger 1 teaspoon toasted sesame oil 1 pound broccoli 1 yellow sweet pepper 2 tablespoons cooking oil 12 ounces skinless, boneless chicken, cut into bite-size pieces 2 cups chow mein noodles or hot cooked rice  directions 1.  For sauce, in a small bowl stir together water, soy sauce, hoisin sauce, cornstarch, ginger, and sesame oil. Set aside. 2.  Cut flowerets from broccoli stems and separate flowerets into small pieces. Cut broccoli stems crosswise into 1/4-inch slices. Cut pepper into short, thin strips. 3.  In a wok or large skillet heat 1 tablespoon of the cooking oil over medium-high heat. Cook and stir broccoli stems in hot oil for 1 minute. Add broccoli flowerets and sweet pepper; cook and stir for 3 to 4 minutes or until crisp-tender. Remove from wok; set aside. 4.  Add remaining oil to wok or skillet. Add chicken; cook and stir for 2 to 3 minutes or until no longer pink. Push chicken from center of wok. Stir sauce; pour into center of wok. Cook and stir until thickened and bubbly. Return cooked vegetables to wok. Stir together to coat. Cook and stir 1 minute more or until heated through. Serve over chow mein noodles or rice. If desired, garnish with toasted sesame seed and serve with additional hoisin sauce. Makes 4 servings.

Zombie apocalypse coming, you have your guns, axes and friends. And well your friends can't be a reliable choice all the time. They can leave you behind so you can die alone. Oh well let's say about the game. We have new guns, zombies. We have CEDA workers, clowns, mudmen, hardhat workers, S.W.A.T cops and fallen survivors Some are invincible to shots form front or fire, some attract the horde of bloodthirsty zombies, some don't hear the pipebomb,some just leave splats of mud on your screen and some carry supplies which makes them very valuable. Oh well, they are infected. New special infected are Spitters who spit acid right at your feet, Chargers which will charge at you (DUH) and pound all living crap outta you (Don't try to shove them back, they are like tanks or witches), Jockeys who will ride you into fire, acid or other dangers. We have incendiary and explosive rounds. Incendiary ammo will light your target on fire (DUH) but this fire lasts just 4 seconds. Explosive rounds are like splash bullets which will damage the infected near place where the bullet hit, they also stun special infected. Boomer bile will work like a friendly pocket boomer, but it's his bile. It will attract the horde on the area where bile landed, and will cover the screens of special infected with boomer bile (It really does, i experienced that on Versus). Defibrillator is a very good tool for reviving your mates which were killed by infected. An adrenaline shot is a tool which should be used when you are doing long actions and you need a speed boost, also they heal you for a small amount of temporary health. We have Scavenge mode which is actually a gas can race, Survivors must fill a generator with random amount of gas cans and the Infected must stop the Survivors from filling a generator. Mutations make the game different, like the mutation 'Taaaank!!' it replaces ALL special infected with Tanks, which adds more challenge to the game. Well i recommend this game for everybody who loves violence and killing zombies... or playing as them.

Left 4 Dead 2 is a fun first-person shooter designed around teamwork. You must stay together to survive or die alone in this zombie survival game, where you take on multiple different kinds of zombies like the boomer who will puke on you, attracting a large amout of regular zombies, or the smoker who constricts and chokes you with his tounge. There are at least 10 campaigns to play and each of them offers diverse gameplay experiences, allowing gamers to find one they like the most and play it a couple times, then go onto a different one and find even more fun to be had. Or if you're bored of campaign mode, simply jump into a versus game were you not only control survivors, but when that round ends you get to play as one of the zombies too! And if you get bored of everything like the mutations which allow for certain rule changes, and the realism mode you can go into the steam workshop and download some custom content like new skins, mutations, maps and even mods which allow almost anything!   Overall I give it an 8.5 on my Like-O-Meter.

Like a good sequel should, Call of Duty: Ghosts doesn’t ignore the formula of fast, fluid gameplay that has made the series famous, but introduces a unique new premise, unprecedented player personalization, and sweeping changes that breathe new life into the multiplayer experience. It’s over-the-top and at times unnecessarily complex, but serves both current and next-generation consoles with ambitious new ideas and tremendous replay value.  Despite sharing a name with one of Modern Warfare’s best-known characters, Ghosts takes place in an entirely new Call of Duty universe set in the not-too-distant future. In a genre overwrought with antiquated Russian conflicts and ambiguous Middle Eastern terrorist threats, Ghosts takes on a refreshingly unique premise in which the threat comes not from the east, but the south: a federation of oil-rich South American nations rises to take over the hemisphere, pushing north and coming to blows with the U.S.  The prelude establishes a harrowing vision of a United States homeland that's broken but not beaten – not quite Red Dawn, but not Fallout 3, either. It’s a space not often explored by modern shooters, and its mood is heightened by missions set in a besieged Santa Monica and the wasted remains of San Diego, to the tune of an excellent, somber score from David Buckley (The Town, Metal Gear Solid 4). But ultimately, time on the poignant homefront is short lived as the story goes behind enemy lines in Caracas, the Andes mountains, and other exotic locales.  Those might lack to familiarity, but the variety of environments keeps the campaign fresh, not only in terms of visuals, but in gameplay as well. Instead of just fighting waves of enemies through a linear stage at ground level, you’ll find yourself rappelling down skyscrapers, flying helicopters, having firefights in space, commanding tanks, scuba diving through shipwrecks, playing as a dog, and evading shark attacks. Each requires new strategy, acute situational awareness, and – in the case of the space and water missions – special consideration for verticality and physics.  Of course, it wouldn’t be a Call of Duty game without elaborate setpieces, fierce shootouts, and tense stealth missions, and Ghosts delivers some of the most memorable experiences in the series. I felt genuine dread as the ground and buildings collapsed around me during orbital weapons strikes, the zero-gravity spectacle of the Federation’s space station ambush is awe-inspiring, and bursting through a highrise window as the entire building crumbles during the Federation Day mission is exhilarating.  But like previous CoDs, the story of Ghosts struggles to remain in focus amidst the fray of explosive cinematic moments and relentless firefights. Narrated loading sequences with stylized story animations push the campaign forward, but only last for one or two minutes before launching back into the action. It’s there, on the front lines, that much of the plot progression is presented and oftentimes lost.  It's by no means an achievement in dramatic storytelling — it's more about dumb fun — and it lacks the player-choice element introduced with Call of Duty: Black Ops II, but when given time to breathe Ghosts actually offers some interesting human drama. The story centers around two brothers, Logan and Hesh, their father Elias, and yes, their dog Reilly as they fight the Federation as part of the battered remnants of the U.S. military, and later as the elite Ghosts squad. The family ties, specifically the relationship between Logan and Hesh, made me care about the protagonists in a series that's habitually made its characters a dispensable commodity. The voice acting is decent overall, though there are periodic moments of cringe-worthy dialog, like one superfluous moment when Elias reveals he’s a member of the Ghosts. And then there’s Riley. Though the subject of many a meme at this point, Riley not only acts as a useful tool for recon and silently dispatching enemies, but is integral to several dramatic sequences, saving your character on more than one occasion.  The story stumbles in the second act when it strays away from the more evocative character focus in favor of a long stretch of back-to-back missions driven almost exclusively by guns-blazing combat. While not poorly done, this visually arresting, action-packed, but ultimately hollow middle stands in stark contrast to the effective first and final acts. On the bright side, that padded out my play time to roughly 10 hours, making this campaign one of the longest CoD single-player experiences.  The Verdict Call of Duty: Ghosts isn't a reinvention of the franchise, but proves there's still room for innovation within its existing formula. Though at the risk of overcomplicating things at times, its robust multiplayer gameplay, surprisingly fun co-op modes, and lengthy, challenging, and varied campaign makes Ghosts one of the best Call of Duty games to date.

This game is about 4 players who attempt to survive and make it to a safe room. There are several different types of Special Infected who try to prevent you from making it into the safe room. The Smoker grabs you from a distance with his tongue, the Charger charges you and pounds you into the ground (he can sometimes charge you off cliffs which can insta kill you) and has high health and high damage from punching you, the Hunter does athletic jumps and pounces on you to rip you to shreds, the Jockey jumps on your back and tries to steer you off the map or into danger, the Boomer pukes on you and makes common infected attack you, makes you take increased damage, and obscures your vision, the Spitter spits goo which hurts you and blocks your path, the Tank punches you away, has extremely high health, can throw cars and other objects at you, can lob rocks at you, and the Witch sits around the map or wanders around crying and 1 hit incapicatates you if you startle it (or kills you depending on the difficulty), although she can be completely avoided most the time, especially if you turn off your flashlight. There's nothing more fun than blasting a bunch of zombies with your friends or competing against them in VS. Once you complete the campaign, you should really jump into VS., it is extremely fun, especially with friends. Sure, the game can get frustrating sometimes but it is my personal opinion that this is one of the greatest co-op games (if not THE greatest) on PC and it becomes twice as fun with friends. Community made maps and mods make this game twice as great, and they give the game much more replayability. Overall, if you don't own this game you should really get it, it is very cheap during sales and very worth the money.

This game is brilliant.  The source engine straight away makes it amazing. Brilliant responsive controls, beautiful graphics and stunning light. Sound is also important in a game like this, and that can only be described as chilling, hearing a zombie right behind you in the dark.  The gameplay is amazing, it really built on the first in my opinion. The best zombie apocalypse game of its kind (not hardcore survival like DayZ), and my favourite game for PvP and 4 players against an environment. Incase you don't know, you get a pistol with infinite reloads, and can get a primary weapon, and either get a second pistol, a better pistol or a melee weapon. There are several safe rooms, which you start and end each level in where you can restock, and you have an aim which is getting from one place to another, and there is usually a horde bit (turning on power so a helicopter can find you, but also alert zombies for example).   There is only one tiny problem with this game, which is the AI. Valve is normally ace at making AI, but here they failed to balance them between being a shooter character, and survival support character.  The icing on this cake of near perfection is workshop support. New campaigns, weapon mods, and my favourite: cosmetic mods. Ever wanted to make bottles of pills cans of duff? You can do that! Ever want to be chased by hordes of tellitubbies? YOU CAN! Ever wanted to play as master chief, with ghost rider, a my little pony character and iron man? Me neither, but you can all play as velociraptors!  This game does everything it was made to do perfectly, if you play with 3 friends.

Left 4 Go fix your own game Bugs 2!   That's right boys and girls, this is the new title for this great game that became a garbage can. I have almost 6,000 hours in this game, so without doubt I enjoyed it since the release date until the past few months when this game became a garbage can.   First, I want to talk about the good stuff about this game:  - Each game you play will always be different even if you played the same campaign over and over: Means when you start a campaign and you finish it, then you restart the same campaign you will have a totally different experience from the campaign you played earlier. This is because all the events that happens in the game are randomized. You cannot tell when or where a special infected will spawn and attack you. You cannot tell when a horde will attack you. This makes the game always different no matter how many times you play it. This is very important to some people because some people, like myself, gets bored fast from games that are not randomized. For example, I played 'The Last of Us' story. The story was so great, but it is repetitive. The enemies spawn in the same exact locations on the map every time I play the game. It is like watching the same movie everyday for years. On the other hand, I never got bored of playing Left 4 Dead 2 after all of these hours I spent playing it, mainly because of these reasons I mentioned earlier.  - The game can be modded: I have more than 100 mods. Many people when they visit my Twitch channel they ask me if this is Left 4 Dead 2 or not, because of the amount visiual changes I made to the game! You can change so many things in this game. You can change your guns, for example, you can replace the M16 rifle with an AKS 74u submachine gun mod, or you can replace it with an M4 rifle mod, or you can replace it with a better looking M16 rifle that was created by another user. You can download multiple mods for the same gun, such as the M16 rifle and use them, one at a time, depending on your mood! I You can change the main characters that you control, for example, you can change Nick from Left 4 Dead 2 with Leon from Resident Evil. You can change so many things in this game. This refreshes the game no matter how old it gets.  - The game is still alive: You will always find random people to play with no matter what time or day you play the game. When I play co-op campaign, I only play on Expert Difficulty (the highest difficulty), yet I always get 3 other players to play with no matter what campaign I play.  - The game is balanced: There are no overpowered enemies in this game, even the big giant tank is not overpowered. However, there are overpowered weapons in this game. For example, the sniper rifles in this game are overpowered because they barely have any recoil, they are powerful, and they have a lot of bullets in each magazine. You can use scope to aim at a target, and shoot so many bullets rapidly with very little recoil. But I am not complaining since this game is not a simulator game.  - Be the survivor or be the zombie: I personally love to be the survivor for multiple reasons. For example, I love to use guns. To me guns are like fruits, I love them. This is one of the main reason why I like FPS games, it is because I love to use guns.   - No one man army in this game: No matter how good a player is, he will always need all the support he can get from his teammates.   - Bots are decent and reliable: I finished all the campaigns on Expert Difficulty with 3 bots, except Cold Stream campaign because that campaign is so difficult on Expert Difficulty even for 4 good players playing it together. Once you play the game a lot and understand the game's mechanics you will be able to manage the bots more efficiently. Yes the bots act dumb, but if you manage them correctly they are very powerful.   - The enemy AI is decent: No matter how good you and your team are, the enemy AI is very challenging. You are going to constantly watch your back while playing against the AI, especially if you are playing on the highest difficulty where the AI does a lot of damage to you.   Let me now talk about why I do not recommend this game anymore to anyone!  - Lag: I have a lag issue that strikes the servers I connect to for the past few months. For the past few months, I get lag strikes after I spend 2 hours playing the game. The pings for me 'and for all other players who are connected to the server I am connected to' gets extremely high for too long until everyone decides to disconnect from the server. Once this lag starts it will strike almost every server I connect to as if someone is following me and is launching DDOS attacks against the servers I am connected to. I contacted Steam for help, but they told me they do not support server related issues and refused to help me out. I checked the forums about people having the same issues, but I could not find a solution. I even rented my own server for $16 a month from GameServers company, and I am still paying for it until this day, but I am still having the same problem.  - Game gets stuck in the loading screen when loading the next level within a co-op campaign: Almost every campaign I play, the game will stuck at the loading screen for one of the levels, and will not load the next level. I noticed that this a problem with a lot of people, and not just me. For example, a lot of time I play co-op with other players I see the bot's name with the word 'IDLE' next to it instead of seeing the player's name. This means the level was not loaded yet for that player. Then we keep moving forward until the player disconnects from the server without being able to join us in the current level we are playing. Again, this is a problem that I cannot find a solution for, and it is a common issue that a lot of players are experiencing.   - Bugs in the game slots: This is one of the problems that I see at least once every few days. While playing a co-op game, and one of the players leave the game, the game slot that this player left contnues to be reserved for that player as if he is still playing. This prevents anyone from joining the game and using the slot that was left off by the player who left the game. You might ask me 'How did I know that no one is able to join because of this bug? Maybe no one was playing the game during the time this happened to you'. Here is something that happned to me so many times in the past. A lot of times when I start the game with 3 other players in the lobby, I end up getting separated from everyone else. Meaning the game creates a new game for me that is separate from the game I was going to play with the other 3 players. For example, I might create a lobby to play Hard Rain campaign with 3 other players. But when I start the game the game creates a Hard Rain game for me only, and creates another Hard Rain game for the other 3 players who were with me in my lobby. When this happens, no one joins the new game I connected to because the 3 game slots are still reserved for the 3 players. I tested this with my friends before. This is a confirmed bug.  Left 4 Dead 2 is now a garbage can. I absolutely do not recommend this game until Valve fix these severe issues with it. I am very sad that Left 4 Dead 2 is my favorite game, but I am forced not to play it as much as I want because of these bugs that I cannot find any solution to because no one is helping me out. I put so many hours playing this game because I really loved it from all of my heart. Believe it or not I spent more hours playing Left 4 Dead 2 than the hours I spent after I got my Bachelor's degree in Science!   Even with all the bugs that this game has, I will continue to play it and stream it at my Twitch channel. I just can't stop playing this game. But it is because I got addicted to it. On the other hand, if these problems happens to you, you will simply remove this game from your game's library.

Repitive,shallow,life-less,corny. These are the words that perfectly describe this over rated shooter. Everything from gunplay, to voice acting is boring. I have never played a more horrible game and I will describe why I think it's just that in this review.  Campaigns / Maps : To start things off, lets go to what's important in a shooter, or almost anygame for that matter. The map(s). The game comes with a base of 5 campaigns, which will be extended to 7, and combined with the original Left 4 Dead maps. Pretty cool, except it makes the people who bought the original feel like a chump, also giving no point to see what the original was like. Not that you need too, it's the same drawn out boringness that's here. Back on topic, the maps are an absolute mess! Often making players lost, confused, or stuck. It doesn't help that each campaign has it's own 'theme' of colors, making finding a door a lot harder thanks to everything being a nice ugly pale yellow, or what ever campaign your doing. Dark Carnival is dark grey, Swamp fever dark green, The Rain one, dark brown, and so on. Not many nice colors. To sum this up, Horrible art direction, (not calling the graphics bad as its hard too when the game is so old) confusing and mindless map design. Fantastic, probably my least favorite part of the game.  Gunplay: Not a whole lot to say here, short selection of weapons bundled with *soft* shooting and high damage rates leaving you feeling like your in a broken game. Oh wait... On topic though, you have three assault rifles, two uzis, four shotguns, two sniper rifles (so useless when this is a run and gun type shooter, even players mock eachother for using them) and about 10 melee weapons which all have the same stats, one hit kill but the katana is faster. The difference between these weapons are so nonexistant that it's insulting! The pump shotguns are the same but ones shiny, the uzis are the same but one has a silencer which still alerts the zombies, auto shotguns have the same story and so on. Literally every weapon is a clone of eachother except the Scar-H rip off which has a 3 burst fire option, which doesn't help much... The sum of gunplay? Overkill with *soft* shooting and useless clones of eachother so you truly only get 4 guns (including the useless sniper) and 2 melee (katana and the rest).   Voice Acting / Story / Writing : There's almost none, this would be fine if the game embraced but no. They try to hamfist and force 'character' down your throat by making each character a cheap stereotype or exaggeration. There's no backstory to each character, no reason there their except the 5 seconds of them saying 'welp the chopper left us'. Sum of this is that there's no story, voice acting and writing is pointless, unfunny and boring.  Bugs,slip ups, etc. : I can finally say something decent about this and that's there not many bugs, atleast not gamebreaking or annoying bugs. You might see a zombie or too get caught in a wall maybe a few stand around like a fool but it's not common and this section is actually quiet clean. Good job (for once)  Overall : Simple done bad, it tries to be a simple fun zombie shooter but fails. It tries to rely on gameplay not story by cutting it all out but fails when the gameplay is so nonfluid and shallow, not to mention it's horrible *writing* of each character. This game has a major identity crisis and is truly one of the most over-rated games I've ever seen, seriously more hyped than No Mans Sky. I can't find ONE good thing about this game beside it not breaking. Do not buy!  *not going to give a number score on this one since it's so negative and anyone reading gets the point to NOT BUY*

The chief difference between this and a standard FPS is that you cooperate or die. Some of your enemies have special abilities that *incapacitate* you, and thus a team mate is needed to rescue you.  If you like solo play, don't worry; the game provide bots to help you in your attempt to survive the zombie apocalypse.  Amazing game, even for those who don't like FPS (like me)!  Okay, so why the negative review?  1) I'm an achievement hunter, and some achievements are unobtainable (special events that happened in 2013 and 2012). That is a turn down. Developers should respect more achievement hunting.  2) Hostility. This is a game that screams for co-op, but your random internet buddy is pretty much an angry 12yo boy who does nothing but eat doritos and play L4D2 as a 'pro'. Nobody will help you to learn the game when you play online! Playing solo campaigns won't help you much with online gameplay practice, in spite of what the 'pros' think. Other than the regular aim-and-shot, the styles can be *very* different e.g.   - You don't need to care for the well-being of the bots (they save you and each other), but you need to when playing with humans  - Bots are always close, kissing range, because they shoot through you. They can save you rather quickly; real humans tend to spread more imho, probably because of friendly fire.   - A bot won't kick you out for a single friendly fire incident. Human players will curse your 7th generation, kick you, backtrace you and ♥♥♥♥♥slap you.  - Human players RUSH - maybe even too much sometimes - and they will leave you behind if they see a safehouse... but bots love you and will never do that! Spoiler: They will die with you instead <3!   - Once again... bots will never call you... anything. Nor your mom.  If you insist in playing this game, go to forums and ask somebody to help you with learning the game and play some campaign together. Make it clear that you're not good (yet). That's the only way to actually practice, not solo. That being said, its not like its a skill you put in your curriculum, so save yourself some time and skip this game.

Left 4 Dead 2 is so content packed, it'd be redundant to get L4D1 to go with it. Left 4 Dead 2 has around 6 of its own campaigns that are all really good and follow 4 new survivors in their struggle to get to safety. The new survivors are still memorable, but not as classic as the original 4. Don't fear, however, as L4D2 comes with EVERY CAMPAIGN FROM THE ORIGINAL GAME AND ITS SURVIVORS. You can't mix and match the survivors, however, campaigns use either one set or the other. There's a host of new weapons, including the amazing M60, a slew of awesome melees, and a Grenade Launcher. The game does stray away from the original's Survival Horror roots, and focus more on being fun and over-the-top, which might bug some dishard fans of the original, but I found it to be more fun than ever before. On top of all this content, there are survival maps, various mutations that alter the rules, and hundreds of fan-made skins, maps and musical cues, allowing players to customize the game their way. For a $20 game, there is a ton of content, and is absolutely worth the price.

Left 4 Dead 2 Retrospective Review™  Left 4 Dead 2 is one of my all-time favorite games. I might as well be up-front about that.  The TL;DR review of L4D2 is, buy it. Buy it for you, and buy it for your friends.  The longer read:  Gameplay in Left 4 Dead 2 started out with basically three options: Single Player, Co-Op and Versus.  Single Player does what it says on the tin - you can go through the campaigns to get to learn the maps before heading into Versus Mode.  Co-Op is your chance to try out L4D2 with other people - it's a nice way of experiencing the harder difficulty levels of the game.  Versus Mode is where the meat of the game is, in my opinion. Two teams of 4 players take turns playing either the Survivors or the Special Zombies. The two teams then compete for points, earned by getting the farthest in each stage of the campaign. The best scores are reserved for the full 4 Survivors making it through the maps, and without using the Defibrilator to resurrect fallen friends.  Since launching the game, Valve has added different 'Mutations' which fundamentally alter the gameplay. There are both Single Player and Multiplayer Mutations. You might play the Taaaaaaanks! mode, in which all Infected players control the deadliest Special Zombie: The Tank.  Furthermore since launching the game, Valve has added all the campaigns and Survivors from the original Left 4 Dead, so you can play with the updated mechanics, graphics and zombies for free. Valve has also added two campaigns which take place between Left 4 Dead and Left 4 Dead 2.  The story of Left 4 Dead 2 is told - as it was in the first- more or less through random voice clips from the survivors, and from grafitti on the walls. It is, you might say, 'story lite'. You don't need to know much more than that you need to either get from Point A to Point B, or you need to keep the Survivors from getting to Point B.  Left 4 Dead 2, even in its 'vanilla' form had tons of replayability. With all the extra content Valve has added (including the custom campaign 'Cold Stream' by a community member), it has even more. Your money-to-playtime ratio is off the wall. At the time of posting, I have almost 280 hours in L4D2, and I still enjoy it immensely - it is, in fact, my go-to game when I feel like I have nothing to play.  Cons to Left 4 Dead 2:  Left 4 Dead 2 is best played with friends. 3 friends to fill up the Survivor team for Co-Op, and 7 friends to fill up both teams for Versus. If you happen to do particularly well in a 'pub-stomp' team (a team pre-made with friends), you might get an opposing team that ragequits before the game is over. That can be frustrating.  Playing with randoms is not always the best experience either - you get your typical:  'Kid who has the mic always on' 'kid who screams at you'  'Person speaking language other than English'   ...as well as people who will vote to kick you from the game - regardless of whether you've done something wrong, and sometimes if you're doing better than the rest of your team.  The graphics work, but are kinda dated (seeing as the game is from 2008).

The maps had a different feel compared with Left 4 Dead. The concept of setting up for an enemy team is far different, now with the understanding that it is more rare to have a full team of incapacitating infected. The maps are more set for a length setup, rather than an up and down system that L4D1 was known for. The added weapons created a new perspective of play, along with melee weapons, different types of ammunition, and even exhaustible weapons (grenade launcher, m60, and chainsaw).   The feeling of this game was much more abrupt. Whereas in Left 4 dead 1, where you would keep moving, while still a little slower, while being hit by zombies, you could continue motion. Whereas, here, it become a staunch, grabbing, feeling, which means that you must stop and encounter the enemies, or risk having your team run along, and someone be left for dead (pun intended) by the rest of the team not being stopped by the grabbing hands of the enemy infected.  All in all, it was a good game, and has given way to interest in the third installment. Looking forward to where they take this franchise, hopefully to some kind of town.   Wouldn't it be hilarious, if they made some kind of mmorpg based off of this franchise, with similar graphics and style of play, but with more expansive maps, or simply by making loop backs, not making maps bigger, but making a map system connecting all the maps. Similarly to borderlands?

Zombie over-saturation notwithstanding, L4D2 is in its best moments a true classic. I find that the chess-piece like 'Special Undead' archetypes actually grow on me, vs. becoming stale — but the thing that makes the game really stand out is the co-op elements. As with most any multiplayer romp, the quality of your experience is of course tethered to the investment/energy/skill of your teammates. L4D2 is notable, however, for the way the game ingeniously, surprisingly, and ruthlessly plays upon that dynamic. While the fabled 'Director' AI isn't like to become sentient anytime soon, it is rather effective at nipping your group in the collective butt to step up the teamwork, and savagely exploiting your vulnerabilities if you're not playing together.  Thus, it's still as uneven as the squad you end up in, but often more engrossing and rewarding as a social experience than you'd expect from a game with bottomless hordes of cannon fodder as a core mechanic.

Left 4 Dead 2 is a cooperative first person shooter game set in the apocalypse. Left 4 Dead 2 is set in the aftermath of a worldwide pandemic of an infectious disease known as the 'Green Flu' Which transforms humans into zombies. The games protagonists Nick, Ellis, Coach, and Rochelle are immune to the infection and seek to escape from the outbreak.  The games antagonists Common Infected, Boomer, Hunter, Smoker. Charger, Jockey, Spitter, Witch, and Tank are all set out to kill the survivors and make sure they never escape.  Left 4 Dead 2's multiplayer is where the game shines, whether it's:   Versus, (4v4) based gamemode where you play through the campaign as usual however, human players are on both teams. The team that makes it the furthest as survivor gets more points and therefore wins that round.  Realism Versus (4v4) based gamemode, however it's more of a hardcore setting and makes the game more difficult. The team that makes it the furthest as survivor gets more points and therefore wins that round.  Scavenge (4v4) based gamemode where the goal is to collect up to 22 gas cans to fuel up a generator (or car) this is a timed gamemode and each time you fill an objective up you get extra time, and points.  Mutations are modified game modes, that add twists to the game for fun or extra challenges.  Survival (4vs infinite hordes) The longer you stay alive the better the score and medal you earn. This is a fun way to compete with friends and beat their highscores. Left 4 Dead 2: Purchased on the 19th of May, 2011, and at the time of writing has amassed 1,847 hours of playtime. This is the game where I made my first friends on Steam, some of which still remain on my friends list to this day. This is the game where I met my sweetheart. How can I not recommend this game?   Left 4 Dead 2 is a zombie massacaring simulator where you play as one of eight badasses and shoot, slash, shoot, burn, shoot, explode, shoot, and shoot again... your way through hordes and hordes of zombies. Some special infected are thrown in the mix by the AI director to spice things up a bit, and if that  still  sounds boring, there are plenty of mutators to change the game up. Maybe that doesn't sound boring, but you're afraid of getting bored after you've played all the maps, to which I'll say: Never fear, the AI director helps keep the maps fresh time and time again, but if even that fails your picky gaming desires, there are plenty of custom campaigns to choose from in the workshop.  Not in to killing zombies? Join 'em! Left 4 Dead 2 also doubles as a survivor hunting simulator, where you play as one of seven decomposing badasses and bite, scratch, bite, vomit upon, bite, hump, bite, and bite again... four of the eight aforementioned surviving badasses as you try to prevent them from reaching the saferoom at the end of the level.

Left 4 Dead 2 is a co-operative video game released by Valve Corporation in 2009 which requires 4 survivors to survive through a zombie outbreak in various maps. This game also includes various game modes such as Versus, Realism, Mutation, etc.  The replay value of this game is very high. Although players are playing on a same map over and over again, but the director will always spawn different infecteds and special infecteds to spice things up, making the round more strategic, requires more teamwork and the whole round just gets tougher. If playing on the original maps all over again aren't what you are fond of, there are tons of websites (Gamebanana, Gamemaps) which allows you to download and play custom campaign missions created by beloved Left 4 Dead 2 lovers! Oh, Steam Workshop works as well.  Besides that, this game requires more teamwork than skill for the most part. Even playing on Normal difficulty, if players don't stick together, special infecteds can take down a team of 4 easily. If the Normal difficulty is way too easy for you, try Advanced or Expert to spice things up.  In addition, this game runs really well on a stable engine called the Source engine. Although graphics might look dated compared to the present games these days but thats where mods come in handy. There are plenty of High Definition texture packs available in the Steam Workshop which are all created by the community and the best part is: It's completely free!  Finally, Left 4 Dead 1 maps are ported over to Left 4 Dead 2. This will help to ease up the decision in choosing which title to purchase but if Steam has sale going on, I suggest getting both as both are just a masterpiece.  Rating: 9/10

When I first started playing Left 4 Dead (on a public account at a LAN shop), I had always wondered whether the old Counter Strike model would withstand the onslaught of newer better FPS formulas introduced by Battlefield and Call of Duty which are later adopted by EA's Medal of Honor series as well. After all, these FPS games had sliced into Valve's dominance in the FPS market in the early to mid 2000s.  So where do Left 4 Dead and its sequel stand in the modern market?  Simplicity.  Simplicity is lacking in almost every FPS games whether it is developed by DICE or Activision. They are never made for the laid back casual non gamers who don't own a PC for games. Left 4 Dead is truely a game where anyone can pick up a gun, a Katana or duel wielding pistols and still complete the run from zombies. Still, there is a great level of mastery to pick up when playing online in competitive mode.  After the various incarnations of Zombie killing games on the market, Left 4 Dead (whether it is 1 or 2) is still the ideal zombie killing LAN party game to date. Fortunately, there isn't a lobby group for Zombie Rights.

Left for Dead 2 is a game that is lots of fun. In small doses. The idea of surviving a horde of zombies is a pleasant one to most people, and I leave this game installed on my computer all the time. Not because I do not like the game, but because it is really, really repetitive, the replayability, which is what games such as this strive and survive on, is lacking. You go through the same linear path every time you play the level, there are no second routes of hidden tricks. You MUST go down that alleyway. While I know it not an open world game, going through the same thing every game, each lasting usually half an hour or more, gets incredibly boring. The game is good, but it needs more diversity. 7/10

Don't think there's much left to say about LFD2 that hasn't already been spoken. Since it's release in 2009 LFD2 has still managed to hang on and maintain a steady playerbase, something that speaks for itself and something many games are unable to say. The game, although simple in premise, manages to pull you in and keep your attention, and even going on 5 years later still gives you an urge to play. The game retains a replay value, although due to the games simple premise of point and shoot and it's basic plot of 'just kill as many zombies as possible' the game can become tedious over time. Luckily the game has had many updates, content patches, and an active modding community. All in all, even though the whole Zombie Genre is sort of reaching it's peak, and in some people's opinions already played out, LFD2 still manages to captivate players.

Ironic that a game inspired by the 'Rage' brand of zombie movie (thanks Boyle) prompts so much RAGE!!11!1!! in the gamers themselves. L4D2 is a mostly four-player adventure through a landscape populated by a ruined human race infested with some sort of rabies mutation. Their sole focus is kicking your head in, while yours is running through hundreds of like-minded head-kickers to rescue. Versus mode is easily the most fun. Two teams of four take turns acting as survivors or the 'special' infected, who are superhero versions of the infected with abilities of super-jumps, or super-spit, or super-barf, etc.  The problem with this game is also its greatest appeal. It requires strong teamwork. Much like a rather well fitting corset, fall out of the tight teamwork this game demands and you end up looking like a fool, embarrassingly exposed to the world, before getting the stuffing kicked out of you. But get it right, and you look and feel stunning. BTW, I've never worn a corset.

Pretty much everything that was promised in Left 4 Dead 1 ended up here. Its a good game to kill some time if you have nothing better to do. It's even more fun when you play with friends. So when you get bored of trying to reach the end of each level, you can take on an endless wave of Zombies to the death. The games also keeps things interesting with an AI Director. The AI Director will change the game to keep you on your toes. If you are doing too well, you may get an extra tank to take on. If you are struggling, expect to see some health kits on the way. Also, there is many 'special zombies' which require you to be alert the whole game.  Cons: I can't think of any except it is definitely a multiplayer game. While you could play by yourself, it gets boring and repetitive without a good group of friends.

Left 4 Dead 2 has you making your way through zombie filled levels with 3 other players (or bots) that you have to work with to survive. The game really shines in its multiplayer, as it forces you to work with your team. Spliting up or going ahead can easily get you killed or trapped, and do the same to your team. Through most of the game you will be running and gunning through levels in an arcade style of play, and that's not a bad thing. It gives you an awesome feeling to rush through a crescendo event with a katana slicing through zombies on your way. Even though this game has a lot of content to offer, it gets old after a while, and I always find myself wanting more. They sort of fixed that with workshop compatibility, but nothing beats the original style levels carefully made by Valve.   When it's all said and done, I would give Left 4 Dead 2 a solid 8/10.

This is an older game, but it's still pretty good. If you don't yet know, it's a fairly simple game where you kill zombies... It goes something like this:  1) Pick up a frying pan 2) Open the door 3) BELT THE CRAP OUT OF THE ZOMBIES!!!! 4) Move through the map, repeating step 3 as necessary 5) Find the safe room and close the door. 6) Repeat on the next level.  Of course, there are other weapons available... Chainsaws, cricket bats, axes etc, plus a whole range of guns. But trust me, stick with the frying pan; nothing else gives the same level of satisfaction.  Just one closing piece of advice: make sure you have at least one other player with you; the AI are definately not the most skilled teammates on earth, and will spend more time trying to heal you then actually shooting the enemy. (They also refuse to use melee weapons, probably because, being AI, they have no sense of how much more fun it is!!)

An epic sequel to Left 4 Dead 1. This expands the AI director's controls from things like swarms and item placement, to lighting, weather, and even routes through the various locations you will encounter. Special themed infected for the various themes also make each one more unique. The new set of characters are just as witty and responsive as the last set, and you still get a customized soundtrack based on your actual play statistics and events. More neat items like the defibulator unit expand the possibilities for strategy as you can only carry one item of each type; should you stick with the defib, or swap out for a medpack or frag rounds? The locations are even more immersive this time around, and there's even a fun crossover campaign between Left 4 dead 1 and 2! Sum that up with a connected story spanning across all the campaigns (L4D 1 had entirely standalone campaigns), and you really get to love the game, the story, and the characters.

Good ol' Left 4 Dead 2, Back for more of kill everything that moves gameplay that everyone loves!  Left 4 Dead's gameplay is basicly the same as it's previous game, Grab a weapon, and beat the crap out of everything that wants to kill you and get the hell out of there.   Most of the changes of this sequel is the addition of different weapons and special throwables, such as the bommer bile jar. With the addition of these, gameplay styles can be dramaticly changed and new techniques be applied when using them.   In the way guns were added, there isn't much to say. The new guns have different damages and styles to use them in.   Other new things include the ammopacks. Instead of the name implying a moveable ammo package, these have ammo that changes the bullet damage. These are the 'Incdiniary rounds' and the 'explosive rounds' and fill 1 clip each.   The original L4D was also included in this game, so you are able to use the new armoury you have at your disposal and try different way to clear the map.   New enemy types have also been introduced to try kill you in different ways!  Gameplay is still fun as always. Valve have stuck to what made L4D so popular and expanded on it to make it even better. Deffinatly a good buy.   Make sure you play with friends though!

You can always tell a sitcom is low on budget when they do a cheap 'reminiscing' or 'flashback' episode that consists mostly of footage from previous episodes. Sometimes it's as blatant and shameless as getting the characters to literally sit around and reminisce, but sometimes the writers get slightly creative and try a more elaborate scenario involving an accident and a coma. That way they don't have to write any dialogue and can just loop footage of some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ lying unconscious in bed while playing lots of teary flashbacks. It could be worse I suppose, considering the alternative is more re-runs of Funniest Home Videos where some idiot gets kicked in the balls week after week.  In L4D2 there's new weapons and new special infected, but the core gameplay is still L4D. It's more of the same really, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. Valve has also re-released old missions from L4D as 'new content' so fans can reminisce. In one of the missions, Bill bravely sacrifices himself to save the team, a tragic turn of events likely to evoke tears of grief from even the most stoic of gamers. Fortunately, this turned out to be a false alarm and Bill was later found alive, inebriated and stuck in a cupboard that he wandered into after consuming one too many Molotovs. Never give Bill Molotovs.

A brilliant co-op Zombie game! The game features not just zombies but 'Special Infected' (which are mutated mega-zombies), each with their own unique attack styles and cruel ways to kill the survivors. Maps range from urban inner city shopping malls, Lousianna swamps and hospital rooftops. The game also allows the player to play single player as a Survivor or on 'Versus' - an 8 player co-op where 4 play as Survivors and the other 4 play as 'Special Infected' and have to kill the opposing team. A good range of guns and melee weapons available (and even more brilliant mods available in the Steam Store). Each Campaign lasts on average 30mins-1hr, depending on skill level and what difficulty you play on. One of my favourite games and it satisfies the need for Zombie-slasher gore and horror.

Very good co-op shooter that has the capability to keep you entertained for a long time. However it's somewhat generic, whilst L4D2 and it's precursor were groundbreaking in terms of shooters and zombie games alike, they tend to stay well within the comfort zone, never really taking big leaps to push the genre to it's limits.  The game is simply run from one heavily barracaded room to another, stopping inbetween to maul a couple of undead hoardes with a chainsaw, which, tends to be what most games do recently. Whilst I can applaud valve for making such an entertaining and well-balanced game, I feel as though so much more could have been done with the game, which is why the workshop is brilliant, I'm very happy to go on the workshop and look at a couple of maps and weapons however a game shouldn't really rely on user content to keep it going, besides the obvious (Skyrim has a very active modding community that are constantly pumping out mods that you never knew you wanted)  The zombies are very well made, feeling squishy and, partly, stupid which is what they should be, they're undead, they shouldn't be running at you, avoiding every obsticle aside from the occaisonal monkey with cymbals *COUGH*CoD Nazi Zombies*COUGH* often hoardes can be taken down easily assuming you've got enough ammo in your gun, but you always have to be cautious moving forward because you can very easily be overwhelmed, which is as it should be. The special infected are all designed to suit special purposes; the Boomer to attract hoardes of infected to your location, the Charger to charge into you, often pushing you off ledges or out windows, the Tank to ♥♥♥♥ your day up, etc.  Overrall I'd reccomend it because it's a fun game to mess around in with your friends, however be warned, once you've seen it once or twice, you've seen it all.

Run away, hack and slash with melee weapons, or just mow down zombies with you gun till you to a safe room. Every mission is basically the same... just different aesthetic surroundings. Typical valve nonsense where guns have uber spread for no reason, and whether or not bullets hit seems to be based on RNG. Like for instance every zombie has like an invisible magnetic force field around it. Sometimes it deflects bullets, and sometimes its like a tractor beam. A zombie can be standing perfectly still, and you can be aiming at it perfect dead center at its head or chest, and the bullet will just randomly go completely astray for no reason 7/10 times. Other times you're not even aiming at the zombie and the bullet will just go astray from where you're aiming and just act like it was magnetically pulled towards the zombie.  Otherwise any other graphic issues, and minor problems I had like for instance if you pick up two of the basic pistols to dual wield... somehow magically the second Sig Sauser pistol turns into a glock!? Which annoyed the ♥♥♥♥ out of me and my OCD, but this was fixable by mods in the steamworkshop.

Counter-Strike is one of the most popular franchises of our gaming culture and is probably the most famous team-based multiplayer shooter of all-time. The first version came out 1999 which means it's been out for quite some time and it's still growing t'ill this day. Counter-Strike: Global Offensive (CSGO) is the latest addition to the game series and also the most successful one so far. I believe that there are three reasons for it's main success. The first reason is primarily because it greats new players well to an environment already filled with veterans. A great example is the games matchmaking system for competitive players which places you with others that are the same skill level. The second reason is how well they managed to implement new weapons and features to the game without destroying it's original charm. It's still the same game from 1999 but with slightly more diversity and variation which enhances the gameplay even more. The third reason is the ability to customize your items appearance, thanks to a community driven workshop and marketplace. The game gets regularly updates which usually feature new items and maps made partly by the developers, but more importantly by the community. You will have lots of fun and tense moments both casually and competitively and I highly recommend playing this game.

Left 4 Dead 2   is an FPS co-op zombie shooter. The gameplay focuses on twitch shooting, and teamwork. This should not be played for an engaging story (although the characters are well developed with witty commentary). Replay value is key here. Level design is fast paced with individual campaigns cut into seperate sections.   Left 4 Dead 2   also comes with the original   Left 4 Dead   campaigns. Making this essentially, two games in one. I should note that it is also highly optimized, with the majority of my hours logged on a laptop.  This game has withstood the test of time due to it's amazing modding community. You name it, there's a mod for it. If there isn't, then it's probably being made. Steam has also streamlined the whole modding process with this title thanks to the workshop. No need to download files and place them yourself. With the click of a subscribe button, your mod is downloaded and installed hassle free.  I highly recommend this game! Buy it, steam sale or not.    tl;dr I like to shoot zombies. tl;dr I like to shoot Stormtroopers as Master Chief.

Left 4 Dead 2 is the sequel to the classic cooperative horror shooter from Valve. The core gameplay remains the same with some new weapons (adding melee to the mix), new characters to replace the originals and new infected to supplement the first set. The game is fun, and all of the original's content has been ported over into this game, but if that weren't the case I would play the original over this one. The flaws are hard to pinpoint, but here are some of them:  - The new characters are hit and miss, and feel more like caricatures  - The game introduces connective narrative between episodes, but it is badly shoehorned into campaigns, and doesn't really add anything - The tone changes from the nihilistic horror of the original (its the end of the world, no help is coming, and you will die) to a camp, B-movie tone with much more humor. Whether you like this is personal preference, but it ruined the immersion for me and reminds I'm playing a game, and a cartoon game at that - The campaigns are set during the day. This sounds minor, but consider how many horror movies have their scary sequences happen during daylight, or how different Alien would feel if the interior looked like the Enterprise D - The level design isn't as tight as the original, and a lot of sequences seem to exist simply to pad the length of the campaign e.g. recovering coke, the Screaming Oak, fueling the car. In fairness, many of these were new features (such as fueling the car) that they tried to add to the game to improve the formula, I just don't think they were very succesful. - The finale of Swamp Fever represents a massive spike in difficulty  - Modding to this game is much more rampant than to the original, and with it many changes that detract from the experience. Many sessions have been modifed to include 8 or more surivors which, frankly, is a cluster and ruins the carefully thought out gameplay (like adding Optimus Prime to a game of chess).  - Finally, many players aren't fun people and create a toxic environement. You can expect to get kicked for being incapicited when you shouldn't have been (in someone's opinion). New players are criticized for not playing amazingly well immediately. Frustrated players will kill their team while still in the safe room, or chastize players for leaving the safe room. (This last one is the most puzzling to me - some teams just want to stay in the safe room. You can't win by staying there, guys, you have to go to the next saferoom).  Overall, a fun time, but L4D2 is much more an expansion pack to the original than a true numbered sequel (something it was flagged for at the time of release), and if the majority of the player base and all of the content weren't present, the original would be the only one worth investing serious time in.

Left 4 Dead 2 is a cooperative first person shooter game set in the apocalypse. Left 4 Dead 2 is set in the aftermath of a worldwide pandemic of an infectious disease known as the 'Green Flu' Which transforms humans into zombies. The games protagonists Nick, Ellis, Coach, and Rochelle are immune to the infection and seek to escape from the outbreak.  The games antagonists Common Infected, Boomer, Hunter, Smoker. Charger, Jockey, Spitter, Witch, and Tank are all set out to kill the survivors and make sure they never escape.  Left 4 Dead 2's multiplayer is where the game shines, whether it's:   Versus, (4v4) based gamemode where you play through the campaign as usual however, human players are on both teams. The team that makes it the furthest as survivor gets more points and therefore wins that round.  Realism Versus (4v4) based gamemode, however it's more of a hardcore setting and makes the game more difficult. The team that makes it the furthest as survivor gets more points and therefore wins that round.  Scavenge (4v4) based gamemode where the goal is to collect up to 22 gas cans to fuel up a generator (or car) this is a timed gamemode and each time you fill an objective up you get extra time, and points.  Mutations are modified game modes, that add twists to the game for fun or extra challenges.  Survival (4vs infinite hordes) The longer you stay alive the better the score and medal you earn. This is a fun way to compete with friends and beat their highscores.  And that pretty much does it for the gamemodes, however another reason this game is so fun is the workshop where you can download mods in the game to make it more fun. You can fully customize the game, and change everything. You may also insert custom maps into your game and the workshop just all around keeps the game fresh and fun.  The game also features the Left 4 Dead 1 campaigns and their characters.   If you're thinking about buying it, do it. It's very worth it, and amazingly fun with friends.

A brilliant co-op Zombie game! The game features not just zombies but 'Special Infected' (which are mutated mega-zombies), each with their own unique attack styles and cruel ways to kill the survivors. Maps range from urban inner city shopping malls, Lousianna swamps and hospital rooftops. The game also allows the player to play single player as a Survivor or on 'Versus' - an 8 player co-op where 4 play as Survivors and the other 4 play as 'Special Infected' and have to kill the opposing team. A good range of guns and melee weapons available (and even more brilliant mods available in the Steam Store). It is essentially as advertised; it's a cooperative zombie shooter. Like most other multiplayer games, it's best played with friends as the experience with unknown people in this game can be very random and frustrating.   The game puts an emphasis on coop, and actually does so well at this, that it almost forces players to play properly - i.e. to stick together somewhat (respecting spacing of course) and to work together.   It's generally a quality product, that contains very few bugs that actually affect the gaming experience. The campaign is slightly short-lived, but can be repeated numerous times without feeling too dull - the difference simply is, that now you know precisely where to go, but it's not like this game is sensitive to spoilers.   There's an array of community built maps that you can venture into as well. Varying in quality, some are great and even quirky in the sense that the gaming experience is completely changed. Others are frustrating bordering on unplayable.   I recommend getting the game - especially if you can convince a few friends to play it with you.

This version however has a good addition of gamemodes! There's a few easter eggs, some of which interactive, new characters, and so on, making it quite a bit more interesting than Left 4 Dead.  What really struck me well though was the addition of addons to the game; now you can customize your game exactly as you want it! Want to shoot planes instead of grenades? Done. Want to chop a zombie down in just that different angle? Done. Sounds? We got 'em. And there's even more to find!  For short; I really like this game due to it's story, characters, gamemodes etc, and the customizability is my definite favourite part of it all. I'd certainly recommend you give it a try if you're into the zombie fps games.

I received the game for free ever since the Christmas event of 2013. I didn't even expect myself to mod the game too. This is the first steam game I have played and even up to now the game has this magnetic personality where everytime I want to play another game I end up playing this one. Known as the successor of L4D1, L4D2 has a lot more content to offer even being superior due to the many game modes and more OS support(playable natively on linux based systems) unlike its predecessor. I can say Valve has done a great job in trying to improve the game. Knowing that the gameplay has minimal differences with its previous iteration I can say this game is great. I love L4D2 and L4D1 its just that I find L4D2 more enjoyable since you can modify the game easily as compared to L4D1. It still receives stability fixes even up to now. The modding community is still active. If you don't have friends then don't fret! You always have those trusty bot modifications to handle the rear end of your team.  TL;DR:   You don't have enough money to buy both L4D1 & L4D2?  Get L4D2  Is there a reason for me to buy L4D1 if I already have L4D2?  I'd say no. You can modify the gameplay as if you are playing L4D1.  Bugs?  Both L4D1 and L4D2 has bugs but L4D2 still has a lot more fixes including community fixes. It's sad that L4D1 doesn't have that much community fixes to the problems it already has ever since.  Larger playerbase?  L4D2  Isn't L4D1 superior?  I don't think so. I think TRS forgot or never cared to support linux based systems natively unlike Valve.  Which game has superior animations?  They're both equal its just that in L4D2 a number of animation sequences haven't been used. The devs of L4D1 were a lot more careful in linking the animation sequences.

Left 4 Dead 2 is a single-player and multiplayer co-operative survival horror FPS game developed by Valve Corporation. It is the sequel to Left 4 Dead, it was first announced June 1st 2009 by Valve Corporation at Microsoft's E3 2009 press conference.  As of January 24, 2010, Metacritic gave Left 4 Dead 2 a metascore of 89 out of 100.  The Left 4 Dead 2 multiplayer demo was released on October 28th, for those who pre-ordered. It was then made available to the public on November 3rd.   The sequel picks up one week after the events of the first game (four weeks after the first infection) where The Infection has spread to the southern United States. Left 4 Dead 2 introduces three new Special Infected, new weapons, melee weapons, new items, upgraded Infected, the Uncommon Common Infected, five new campaigns, and two new game modes: Scavenge Mode and Realism Mode. Realism Versus and Mutations were later released with the The Passing DLC, a new campaign which chronologically fits in as the second campaign out of six.  xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx The four Survivors the players control are Nick, Ellis, Rochelle, and Coach.

Left 4 Dead 2 is a first-person shooter game from Valve. It is a sequel to the previous game Left 4 Dead.  Left 4 Dead 2 lets you play as another group of four survivors on a brand new campaign with a crossover campaign from the first game too. These new survivors are Rochelle, Coach, Ellis and Nick. This sequel has more game modes to play and even more choice of weapons to use against the undead, but there are also new types of special infected too, so be prepared to be amazed, or dead. It seems that Valve finally decided to add Left 4 Dead campaign into this new game, but the feels are different as the new infected also present in the old campaign along with the new weapons and improved graphics, making the game even more replayable.  Left 4 Dead 2 also comes with Steam Workshop support so there are lots of user made custom content you can download to customize your game, like custom weapons, custom survivors, custom infected and special infected, custom maps and event some people made custom campaign with their own story. You can also make your own content and share it with public.  Overall, Left 4 Dead 2 is a really good sequel. I recommend this.    Rating 9/10
