Many people love L4D2, following the incredible success of L4D.  Personally, I think  this game is a heap of ♥♥♥♥  - and I love just about every other Valve game. Technically and graphically, it is better than L4D, and unfortunately, that's the only part it is better. In everything else, it stinks.  Gone is the atmosphere, the friendly rivalry between Louis and Francis, the grainy 70's film effect ( seriously, wtf were you thinking ), dark brooding cityscapes, and the witty repartee between all four members. Instead, you get four unlikeable characters that spend more time whining and ♥♥♥♥♥ing at each other, bright sunny days in New Orleans, and near constant waves of zombies. In fact, that is the main thing that irks me about the sequel. In the first one, if you had a strong member of the team, there was a fair chance they could pull the the rest of the team through, which made for some hectic, but fun, gameplay. In L4D2, there is no chance of that. The waves are too relentless and the specials spawn far too frequently, so if the team is a little disorganised, you're ♥♥♥♥ed with a capital F. Once the game decides it is going to target you, that's it until you either run of medkits or the team gets tired of trying to protect you. More often that not, you're spawning back at the safehouse, because one player got boomed, jockeyed and then incapped in the spitter goo.  Cue ragequitting from less invested members of the team. The fun factor just shines through at that point (/sarcasm)  I've tried hard to like this game, really I have.  God knows I've put enough hours into it, but I just can't bring myself to like it in any way shape or form. In fact, I've gone from trying to like it to hating it, and have completely removed it off my PC. If I could delete it from my Steam library, I would.  L4D may have had it's flaws, but it certainly had atmosphere and characters you could warm to, and my final verdict is that L4D2 does not hold a candle to it. To sum it up - in the first game, you felt like you were all fighting against hordes of zombies.  In the second one, it feels like you are fighting everything in the game - zombies, weather, terrain - some maps are just a  slow grindingly weary slog  from start to finish.  It's cheap enough to pick up for a bit of fun, and you might like it, but I seriously can't recommend it when the preceding game was far  FAR  superior in gameplay.

Is it a game with good production values and amazing Source graphics, with nails-hard gameplay? Yes it is. Does it have an inventive gore system and well-done lighting? Yes it does. Does its moddability extend its life into the aether? Yes it does.  No matter whether I'm shooting Teletubbies or zombies, L4D2 feels to me, ultimately not fun. I get halfway through a level and realize... that's it. I dread the CS: GO like aiming where your aim sort of hits where you point and sort of doesn't. I dread the slog that is the finale, the Dead Center one most egregious of all, since it is so backtracky it hurts. The base levels drag on too long, and while the health system is certainly  very  inventive, the friendly-fire and starvation of healing items feel like a grasping attempt at something resembling 'difficulty'. So yes, I've played it a bit, but only at the easiest difficulty. Glad I got a Source toy to play with Christmas 2013 but ultimately, as a co-op shooter, far too stunted.

I have had a love-hate relationship with Valve's games in general (at least since the Half-Life 1 days, ah how I miss them). Left 4 Dead 2 is no exception unfortunately.  I really liked Left 4 Dead 1's maps and the reasoning behind them (check out the commentary if you get a chance) however they seem to have COMPLETELY forgotten the lessons they learned while developing the first game and have made the series about endless grinding instead of strategic team-work.  This is definitely not what I think of as a 'realistic' zombie survival game but it can be fun with the right team.  I really wish they hadn't re-done the original maps and made them way less fun (i.e. grindy). I found Dead Island in many ways to be much more 'realistic' and much more fun overall (but unfortunately, far less replayable).  Originally, I would have recommended this game as I have uncounted hours into it on the Xbox 360, following the changes that Valve has made, I simply cannot.  Please bring back the meaningful crescendo events, where I do not have to willingly submit myself to damage in an effort to 'push' my way through a unrealistic unending hord. Please bring back maps that have climaxes and lulls. Permanent climax leads to exhaustion or boredom!  Please Valve, stop ruining your games; please do not be the George Lucas of the Gaming Industry!

Left 4 Dead 2 adds quite a bit to the franchise. New guns, special, infected, and melee wepons expand greatly upon the original game. While the new features initially seem to be improvements, it feels as if developers were not content to create a merely challenging, fun experience. The randomness makes for a good replayability value but also means that sometimes, whether you're playing by yourself or with others, on any given difficulty setting, the game will simply screw your odds without hope of recovery. I dislike this aspect and after several hours of jumping that fine line between challenging and unreasonable I have decided that L4D2 gets a thumbs down.
